reviewText:
Update: After the 1.6 update is had been made 100% clear that this game will not last very long at all. I have a feeling it will go under sooner or later so I really wouldn't waste my time on it.

FireFall once allowed you to explore the land and play wherever you want. You had a nice and simple class system where you could pick up a class and start playing it without issues. You could play instances with a brand new class and no one would complain or even notice you were a low level.

That world has gone. The new FireFall (The release 1 year ago) feutures a leveling system. Which forces you to play in set locations until you have gained enough experience points to move on to the next level. Even after playing your faviroute class all the way to level 40 you will be greated for many players typing LFG or LFM into chat. As they're looking for items in instances which are only available at level 40.

You can no longer play any class you'd like. You have to stick in each level zone until you outlevel it. (If you get a class to level 20 but suddenly want to play a different class you have to go back tot he starting zone and play there instead)

You can't really play with friends as if you are 5 or more levels above them one of you is going to have a hard time getting experience points and therefore will end up leaving the lower level behind.

I have been playing FireFall for 2 years but this is where I get off the fanbus and say farewell to all my friends I have met in this virtual world.

I've spent over 150 pounds on this game hoping it would someday become the shining beacon that it had promised to be. Unfortunately this beacon is yellow coloured and I don't like yellow beacons if I'm honest.

If you're looking for a game with repetetive gameplay, an empty and boring storyline with a horribly boring operator talking to you every 5 seconds then this is the game for you! The AI is flawed in so many ways. The 'alien' race is weak and easily killed where as the common bandit will destroy you in a few bullets.

The whole 'horizontal progression' system of firefall went out of the window and now has been replaced with 'vertical progression'

We no longer travel the horizon, we take the elevator.

EDIT: I'm glad so many people agree with me. Maybe this will encourage the developers to re-use or go back to some of the older assets :)

reviewText:
As of the 1.6 patch this game has swapped to, and begun the path down, pay to win. In the patch players had their stats nerfed, movement speed, HKM charge, durability, and those stats were put back in... as 1 hour consumables you can buy.

All vehicle and glider purchases, outside of packs, have been changed to be rentals for up to 30 days. Besides the tutorial bike you have to wait for special events" for offers that get you faster perm vehicles or chances at perm gliders.

Crafting has been disabled until patch 1.8. Endgame zones we had before have also been disabled till that time.

The classes have recieved massive revamps
date: almost all of them are a shadow of their former selves and if you are a returning player then you probably lost a ton of your progress in the migration.\n\nThe game is in a very buggy state
recommended: they had been working on this patch for 9 months prior
hoursPlayed: however due to the chinese parent company The9 pushing the patch before it was ready and layoffs hitting Red5 the entire combat system they worked on over those months was scrapped and reworked 1 month before Friday's release of the patch.\n\nThe old professional voice over work is gone

helpfulPercent:
and rerecord the old lines that were changed.

The real kicker is that this was Red5's last try. If this patch did not massively succeed then the game was going to be shut down in North America and Europe. With its last remnants moved over to China.

It had the opposite effect. The community is enraged. 9 months of feedback
votesHelpful: bug reports

and warning not to push the patch through were ignored. The buggy migration code was pushed out before it was ready under orders from the parent company.

Currently China is not set to recieve the patch. They are using the entire North American and European player base as bug testers before the patch and the migration code goes over to China.

reviewText:
I just realised I didn't reccomend this game. And I don't know why! (TL;DR VERSION BELOW)
Firefall is unique MMO. Why? Because:
1. It's really free - you can even gain pets without paying a single dollar. Just chance for pet is pretty low, but you have 100% for advanced frame YOU want after gaining max level.
2. It's one of VERY rare MMOs, where there are guns, just like in good old shooters, not some auto-attack + abilities. Of course, there are abilities, don't worry, but there's even a class which has... Guns instead of abilities. Yep, 5 weapons instead of them. But ok, onto review here.
BASICSGameplay
Game is set in First Person or Third person perspective - you can change it in any moment. You play game as a mix of typical MMO (like WoW) and shooter (like CoD, but I'd say it's not very similar). There are 5 main character classes which you can change it every moment, you don't need to make new character. Of course every class has it's own level to level. Every frame (they're called like this in game) has it's two advanced versions, which are modifications of main one (with exception of Dreadnaught - he has 3 advances).
Combat
Firefall is shooter + abilities - Left Click to shoot your weapon, right click to use special ability of weapon and press 1-4 buttons to activate abilities. You can also use items from 5-8 buttons, like grenades, medkits etc. Also, there is meele under G, but I don't see many players use it. I'm a fan of it, though. Your primary weapon (each class has it's own locked to them, advanced frames can use their weapons + main frame shooty) has limited ammo, while your secondary one has unlimited. I won't say too much about them, I don't wanna waste space.
Missions and world
There are 8 main missions (more coming with new update. MANY more) which you can do in normal mode or hardcore mode, solo or in group of 5 players. You can take smaller missions from Job Board, but they're a bit boring. But hey! But what if I don't wanna do missions? No problem. Firefall is fully-open world.  You can get anywhere you want, as long as it's not a big melding curtain. Because it most probably will kill you. You can do missions, you can go to randomly-generated events (plenty of them, you won't see many during 1-9 levels, but it will change) or you can just explore world - game even gives you achievements for finding hidden locations. However, game becomes grinding your way after some time, which is sad. You can avoid it, but leveling up this way will take very much time. There are 5 locations - Coral Forest (1-24lvl), Sertao (25-36), Devil's Tusk (37-40), Amazon (40) and Broken Peninsula (Desert where nobody lives. Sad)
Crafting
There is crafting in game, but I won't call it VERY interesting, rather simple and easy-to-go. You place a thumper, a device which mines stuff, you collect things from killed NPCs and then you refine it. You salvage things for research points and crystite (currency), and then you research things like new weapons, modules, medpacks using research points and CY. After you researched a thing, you craft it with more CY and iron/tungusten/whatever/refinedthingsfromenemies. Voila, you've got your gun/module/ability or medpack.
Leveling up
How to level up? Well, you can't level up by messing around city. Do missions, if you have LOTS of free time. Do random events, if you want to or you don't have too much free time. Level up with other guys, there are big numbers of these. I'd love to say PLENTY, but this game is so unpopular. I hope it'll change soon. Maybe thanks to my reviev ;)
But what after leveling up to 40? You can still mess around last location. You can go to Amazon, VERY hard location and try to fight with Chosen (enemies) for forest domination (yep, AI isn't best, but they'll try to capture your bases while you try to do same to them). You can go for raids or hardcore missions for better loot.
STUFFClasses
There are 5 main classes: Dreadnaught, someone who takes tank role, Assault, guy all-about damage and mobility, Biotech, healer (bad at it, tbh. Dragonfly rulez), Recon, NOT a sniper, I'd rather call him light infantry, and Engineer, a painful class to play. Sets up sentries and supply stations. You'll probably choose him as your first class. That's normal, I did same. They're just too weak at higher levels, and without support... Powerful at watchtower retake.
Each class has two (or three) advanced frames. After paying some money or gaining level 40 you can choose one. Each advanced frame has his own set of abilities and weapon, but they can use main frame stuff. They look like this:Dreadnaught - Rhino (DPS) - Mammoth (Tank) - Arsenal (Screw abilities when I can have gunz)
Assault - Tigerclaw (Specialist of PWNing single targets) - Firecat (AoE)
Biotech - Dragonfly (Healer) - Recluse (Damage + poison, healing only with BIO skills)
Engineer - Bastion (Right course for engi) - Electron (Powerful support, but nobody plays as him)
Recon - Raptor (Sniper with charging rifle) - Nighthawk (Sniper with bolt-action rifle)Random stuff
Currency
There are some money" things. We see here: Crystite (CY) - collected from almost everything. Used to almost everything.
Credits (CR) - Collected from final box in small numbers (you gain them after some playing). You can also sacrifice CY for more CR

reviewText:
It takes a lot of talent to ruin a fun game as much as these devs are. I have never seen a company so focused on destroying their own game. The whole thing has only gone downhill in a way I thought impossible.
Playing this makes me wish it was illegal to release games as betas.

Last big update made me lose 80% of my gear and abilities with pretty much ZERO compensation for them, and the comepsation that I did get is worth maybe a day of playing.

The bugs, oh god they're everywhere. They are growing in numbers and nobody can stop them.
Oh, I'm not talking about the enemies there. We are still dealing with bugs that came up during the early builds of the game, and they just keep getting worse with no attempt to fix them.
Pretty much everything not loading in properly? How about we change an unrelated thing that nobody asked for."

The devs are like children trying to "help" their parents with something. They are so focused on adding stuff they think is cool without any care of what will come out of it.
I have never before had a game leave such a bad taste in my mouth."

reviewText:
I've only HEARD the horror stories of 1.6... And they have me deterred from even FINISHING my install for the main client itself.

So, let's go over a history lesson of what the game had right and wrong from start to finish.

So, in the beginning when I start playing the open beta back in August of 2014, the game kicked ♥♥♥. There was so much variety it made my head spin! You could literally keep finding things to do... Thumping, fending off angry Chosen, ARES missions, Chosen Strikes, defending Sunken Harbor and Thump Dump....

That ALLLL ended when the game launched on Steam. The variety of things to do mysteriously vanished, along with the sense of direction the game initially had, quelling all chances of growth slowly as time went on. The first features to be removed of course, were the chosen activities. Next on the list came resource variety, taking away literally EVERY resource, ALL 18 of them, and replacing them with Iron, Tungsten, Titanium and Uranium. The bio- and mech- resources already in the game got more additions, increasing the rediculous ♥♥♥♥ING level of farming and grinding required to even step ONE foot forward in the damned game.

Move on to 1.3, things have gotten even worse with the removal of the Battleframes' variety and reducing the progression style to your basic-♥♥♥ level up system, going even FURTHER BACK from the Constraint system. In addition to this, the unwanted and un-needed focus of story was put into the game, getting in the way of the gameplay itself and literally ♥♥♥♥ING with the pace nine ways from a Jesus' Chicken Sunday.

....

.............

........................

BUT AT LEAST AT THE TIME THE ♥♥♥♥ING DEAF-AND-HALF-A-♥♥♥♥♥♥ DEVELOPERS HAD A SUSTAINED IQ HIGH ENOUGH NOT TO DOUSE THEIR OWN GAME IN GASOLINE AND THEN CARPET BOMB IT WITH CRASHING ZEPPELINS FILLED WITH FOUR CUBIC ♥♥♥♥TONS OF HELIUM, PURE OXYGEN, CONTAINERS OF PURE SODIUM, AND NITROCGLICERIN AND LIQUID ♥♥♥♥ING NAPALM IN SEPERATE CONTAINERS, ALSO ALL IN CUBIC ♥♥♥♥TONS MULTIPLE MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TIMES UNTIL THERE WAS NOTHING LEFT BUT A HORRIBLE DISFIGURED, SMOKING CARCAS SOMEHOW STILL ALIVE BEGGING TO BE SHOT IN THE HEAD FOR IT TO BE OVER WITH.

THIS... Is what 1.6 has done, according to what I've learned. And I DARE NOT get on for the sake of my own sanity. The introduction of lockboxes, Spiral Knights-and-a-half level grinding and farming, and temporary stat boosts have milked what remains of this victimized game for what little left it's worth.

In addition to that, literally EVERY MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING BATTLEFRAME IN THE GAME HAS BEEN NERFED UNTIL IT IS A GOD DAMN FOSSIL DEEP ENOUGH IN THE CRUST TO HAVE SUPPOSEDLY BELONGED FROM THE ♥♥♥♥ING JURASSIC PERIOD OF DINOSAURS. AND OH MY MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING *GOD*, DON'T GET ME STARTED WITH THE INSANE, SADISTIC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T THAT IS REMOVING THE ALTERNATIVE FIRING MODES FROM LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE PRIMARY WEAPON THAT COULD POSSIBLY BE EQUIPPED IN THE GAME.

AND IF *THAT* ♥♥♥♥ ISN'T ENOUGH TO SCARE YOUR STUBBORN ♥♥♥ AWAY, THE ♥♥♥♥ING WALL-OF-CHINA LEVEL OF BUGS WELL DEFINITELY TRY IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE HORRIBLE AUDIO RECORDINGS REPLACING WHAT WAS ORIGINALLY IN THERE ALONG WITH EVERYTHING YOU OWN POSSIBLY BEING DELETED OR RENDERED INTO A RENTAL.

This game suffers from something I call Destiny-itis. WHY Destiny-itis? IT'S THE ONLY ♥♥♥♥ING EXAMPLE ACCURATE ENOUGH TO DEPICT A GREAT ♥♥♥♥ING GAME BEING EXPECTED AND SHOWING ITSELF TO BE SO POORLY DONE IT DOESN'T EVEN QUALIFY AS A 16TH OF SOMEONE'S LEFT FAT ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥ CHEEK.

That being said.... There's literally nothing you can find you'll enjoy here more than you'll enjoy in most other games. HAVING finished my angry, relative rant to this review, I've learned a while ago, to hope for the best and expect the worst. In THAT respect, Firefall hasn't disappointed, but with the target goal of building back its playerbase, it's long since passed the point of no return with Red5 Studios being purchased by a Chinese business company. If you care for your wallet, money, sanity, time, ♥♥♥♥s, ♥♥♥♥♥, happiness and fun,... You won't EVER wish this game on ♥♥♥♥ing ANYONE. NOT YOU, NOT YOUR ENEMIES, NOT YOUR ABUSIVE STEP FATHER. NOT ♥♥♥♥ING *ANYONE*.

reviewText:
I do recommend this game, but only because it's free to play, if you had to pay for it, I don't think it would be worth it.

This game is fun for a while, then it gets a little repetitive, then it gets REALLY repetitive.

In this game you're a battleframe pilot.  In the beginning you can use the basic versions of 5 unique battle frames, they each level independently and though you only have to do the main story missions once, you can replay them all you like.  Each basic battleframe has 2 or 3 unlockable advanced versions, these are unlocked either via cash shop, the player-run market with ingame currency, or using pilot tokens from leveling another frame to level 40 (max level).

The problem is that there isn't a very large variety of things to do, even at the start, there are about 4 different types of random events around the map, there are a few (not nearly enough) area missions you pick up at the bulletin boards in town, or main missions.  After you outlevel the area you're in, you move onto the next one.  There'll be some different monsters/people to kill, but essentially it's all the same.

The even worse problem is that you have to do this for any battleframe you use... There's no different story, no different events or missions, or quests... So essentially you'll do the same thing (which in the beginning is exciting but it only lasts at most a matter of weeks.) over and over again for as many battleframes you want/have.

Having friends in the game to play with only prolongs it so far.

reviewText:
Updated 21st of Augst 2014: New patch, new changes. They've ramped the dynamic content up a lot. For all those complaints about being 'forced' to do Jobs to exp, Red5 responded. You can now go from 1-40 doing nothing but randomly spawned missions if you wanted to. These include things like Chosen drop pods, bandit ambushes, lockbox assaults and similar. They added the mobility to Assault many were asking for, and did a tuning pass on a lot of other frames to fix a lot of problems people were having. All in all the devs have been really responsive to the actual issues.

Of course you'll now see people on the forums complaining that the game is too hard now! All these enemies! We wanted a war not challenge!

All in all they've been doing an excellent job of polishing up what needs polish and adding in new events and trying to work up new live events for the players.

Updated the 9th of August 2014: I just wanted to update this a bit to say that the devs have remained constantly talkative in game, interacting with the community and answering questions and the like. I've gotten a chance to play with quite a few of the crew from Red5 and they are all pretty passionate people.

The forums for this game are turning into a pretty toxic mess, but in game I've seen nothing but positive changes as Red5 continues to try to iterate and get the game more polished. The first few weeks were pretty rough but I've got to meet a lot of cool new players who seem to honestly enjoy the game. Red5 seems to have a direction they want to go and seem to be following it much better then the kind of random experiments they were doing before. After yesterdays Firefall Live I have more faith in their ability to take feedback and data and move the game forward.

Just, you know, avoid the forums. It's pretty much the bottom half of the internet. If youtube and news articles have taught me anything its that you never read the bottom half of the internet.

I've been playing Firefall since near the beginning.

I want to make something clear for anyone who reads the negative reviews: They are horribly nostalgic. The 'constraints' system boiled down to 90% of the population using the same build (Max cooldown and jump jets) so they could fly around in circles and spam abilities without a modicum of skill. Regen was high and it was easy to make yourself literally invincible. The game was incredibly easy and no one wants to admit this because that'd ruin their rosey naval gazing.

On to the game we have now: It's bigger. The world is really well made and has a lot of interesting locations. The different frames all feel different enough to be noticeable. You can hit level cap in a week or less if you just pay a bit of attention to how you gain exp. Crafting currently is too overtuned in that the prices are sky high, but that'll probably get toned down. (Dev's have said they wanted to start high and go down because almost no one whines about having to spend less to build things.)

All in all its a really solid shooter with heavy RPG elements. There are really fun raids at endgame and the instanced dungeons that tell that main story are generally really fun. You can solo all of them (Well not the raid. At least not that I know of.) but they definitely shine with a group.

Also the assault class plays like a Tribes spinfusor soldier. Huzzah to that.

reviewText:
Firefall is a Open world 1st/3rd person shooter similar to tribes. There is resource harvesting and dynamic world events that let you feel like you're in some kind of living world.  If you like playing team games, resource harvesting, basic crafting and killing aliens and bugs then you should like this game.

It's okay for a free to play game, there is time gated content that requires you to level up your stating classes to unlock advanced ones. There is visual styles like paint patterns and color schemes that you do have to pay for. You can pay to unlock advanced frames but you can’t pay to level up the equipment you use.

You can however pay for XP modifiers so you can level up faster, there are random daily incentives that lure you into staying logged in for up to about an hour and to do so daily.

Crafting is time gated with the ability to pay to speed up crafting.

The cash shop has social items as well that don’t do anything other than in game fireworks and junk similar to making pets appear.

You shouldn't waste money in this game, the developers change features and flip/flop on designs when ever they feel like it.

reviewText:
It's a fun game for the first couple of hours that you play it, while you're getting accustomed to the world of the game. Then some of the harsh realities start to hit you.

The game starts you off by allowing you to choose one of several basic classes, like Assault, Dreadnaught, Recon, etc, and upon reaching level 40 (max level) with any of these classes, you are given 10 pilot points to unlock an advanced version of the class. Herein lies one of the game's irritating problems. The grind becomes very, very annoying. It's just continual back and forth between Job Boards, with a few world events thrown in like crashed LGVs or thumpers. It would be fine if it was fun, but once you do it a couple of times, the missions get extremely repetitive and tedious.  One of the annoying ways the Job Board missions can make life hell for you is by forcing you to travel long distances back and forth, and if you don't have an LGV (a type of vehicle) or your glider is on cooldown, it becomes very tedious. Yes, I understand the developers need to make money somehow, and this is clearly a way to make people consider buying an LGV, and that's fine, I just don't like it and I'm warning others.

Unlocking advanced frames is extremely, extremely grindy for a new player that hasn't been in the beta for a long time and already has everything unlocked. Say you pick Recon as your starter class, and you want to unlock one of its advanced classes, the Nighthawk. Unless you straight up buy it with Red Beans (the premium currency), or from the Community Market with credits (another premium currency, you convert between the regular currency crystite <> credits, and credits <> Red Beans; it's not easy to obtain the large amounts of credits needed by exchanging crystite), you're going to have to first go through the grind of leveling up your Recon to maximum level, and then once you've unlocked your Nighthawk, you're going to have to start the leveling process all over from the beginning to level that up. If you want to unlock any other class, now you have to level up the Nighthawk to level 40, etc. etc. Simply put, it's extremely, extremely grindy.

If that wasn't all bad enough, that's just grinding with classes. The grind you have to go through regarding crafting is another pain.

I will say playing some of the classes themselves are fun, but the process of getting to play any of them properly is nowhere near fun.

EDIT: In fairness to the game, I will say that they have done a nice job designing the actual world itself. The graphics look very nice most of the time (unless you get close to any rocks in the game, my god those are ugly). Using gliders and the LGVs feels nice, it's just the process of getting there that's a huge pain. The game's soundtrack was also very nice to listen to.

reviewText:
TL;DR This game is great but there are so many problems that the Devs and other workers dont care about and actively ignore their playerbase. Also give exploiters rewards over more legitimate players.

Buggiest game in the history of gaming.

Now where to start about the people who made the game and run it.
We have a Community manager that seems to have undone all balancing attempts the Devs put out by doing a secret little event (on a server thats hard capped to 180 players) by giving them ♥♥♥♥ tons of XP and elite ranks (could gain 200-400 ER in this little event). making the game really unbalanced and many unlegitimate players stronger and better than everyone else.

You have a community manager and workers that has stated in their IRC chat that they actively ignore most of the forums because its just drama when most of it is legitimate complaints.

You have a community manager that gets salty/♥♥♥♥♥♥ whenever you bring up anything rational or logical to him.

You have developers that don't seem to know how to fix any bugs, their latest update broke one of the main raids (Baneclaw) by splitting up platoons when they enter and if that doesnt happen half of the platoon just instantly die.

You have developers that stated what they have fixed in patch notes only for around only 2-3 of those things to actually be fixed while everything else is exactly the same.

You have 3 communities on this game now. The toxic players that call everyone hackers, noobs or the like. The AFK platooners who just gain XP for free off of the back of other players and you have the legitimate players who are all low Elite ranked because the High and mighty XP platooning High ER players do everything before the legit players have a chance.

You then have these same high and mighty players exploiting everything they can to gain more and more XP becoming even stronger and untouchable that then get a prize of a special secret dev event where they then gain billions more XP because why the ♥♥♥♥ not :/

I'm not saying you shouldn't play this game because you should but the Devs and Community Managers just do not care about anyone that isn't from a chinese server and the community in the past year has just gotten more and more and more toxic to the point where you think you are playing LOL or DOTA 2

reviewText:
Having played the game for over 300hrs Im pretty sure I like it, lol but lets go over the pros and cons.
EDIT: nearly 700 Hours on record.

Pros:
-Open world, go anywhere. Missions are open to anyone.
-Jetpacks make for a interesting dynamic.
- The AI has been improved a lot, they hit things!
-They reward your accomplishments, (each LvL40 gains a perminent stacking+10% exp bonus to your next frame, yes you can have +150% exp on your last frame lol)
-New Events make for interesting things to do, the seiges or theft events, skyhook or OCT, all are things that people can just jump into and do.
-At least amazon has action constantly happening and people call out when something is going on.

Cons:
-The game needs its arena/PvP content back badly. The open area pvp needs to be fixed up or taken out and repolaced with jetball.
-Once you have the Frame you want theres no real reason to level any of the other frames except for perks. and soon we'll have 90 perk points instead of 40.
-They need to continue the story missions which have been untouched for a long time. :(
-Materials for Crafting is getting pretty crazy. *Fixed*
-New content is being worked on and released frequently enough to keep me interested. formally a pro Ive moved this to a con to say that its takes them so long to get this stuff out that my interest drops to the point I log on for maybe an hour or so when Im bored and play but thats it.

reviewText:
This game will trick you into thinking it's good, while it actually is horrible. By that, I mean there are a lot of almost saving graces. The gameplay is fun, the way frames are made to do something wildly different than most other frames is well done. But that's about where the good parts end. I let my hope get the best of me, and continued playing this and progressed quite far, so I've seen everything the game has to offer at this point, as far as actual content. I have 3 frames yet to unlock, but I think they'll probably remain locked forever, because I'm uninstalling. Let me tell you just a few of the completely broken things in this game.

1) Bugs. This game is filled with bugs, left and right. At time of writing, I cannot login, because the login servers are down- DURING A 4 HOUR LONG EVENT. Which leaves innumerable players (including myself) unable to get the rewards from said event. I wish I hadn't logged out, because I'd at least earned credit for the event. But I figured that since my screen was frozen for up to two minutes at a time (Not a problem on my end; CPU, ram, gfx card all WELL within tolerances) I might restart my computer and see if that helped. Turns out, I can't login at all now. That's just one of countless bugs which plague this game from start to finish.

2) The game is a grindfest. You can't play ONE frame. I mean sure, you get to level 40 with your first frame, Yay now I can do the 3 endgame raids there are!" Yeah but not well. The thing is that to get the right perks to make your frame actually decent

reviewText:
When I first heard about Firefall, it was right about the time it went to OBT. The first few hours of gameplay was confusing as hell, because there was no tutorial for crafting, resource gathering, no information about the story etc.

Yet, I dug myself into the game. I wanted to learn it. I poured in it around 200~ hours in open beta. After I understood the mechanics, I was simply sucked in into this world.

It was a sci-fi shooter, with a moderately deep, but quite hard-to-learn crafting/leveling/gathering system.

The idea, that

- a player had the choice to thump (mine) 4x4 different kind of materials
- which each had a quality system from 0 to 1000
- while you had the option to explore the whole map to get the highest quality for your gear
- keeping low quality for the level-ups"

reviewText:
Red 5... what are you smokin on? I don't know what happened to this game within the course of the year i was away, but all these negative reviews made me curious. I just had to go see for myself.

There were a ton of bugs to begin with, sure, but now they have multiplied. Issues from simple animations and graphics all the way to the game mechanics itself. Constant clipping, rubberbanding and horribly long loading times.

Missing/broken equipment. LIterally everything on my characters have been altered to a point that the builds are no longer valid. Even content that required cash purchased no longer work or exist.

This game been one of my absolute favorites for  a long time. Spent a few hundred hours on one steam account (until i forgot it's info) and then a good amount of time on this account. I was happy to have such a vast landscape to openly explore and have borderlandsesque fun with randos. However, instead of improving and fixing the experience that has already been provided, Red5 insists on 'expanding' and 'upgrading' without so much as a second thought to repercussions to the game's integrity and it's player base. The changes themselves won't deter newer players, but the inconvenience and bugs that come along with them certainly will.

I guess it's time to move on.

reviewText:
Firefall has a personality disorder. Its centerpiece is supposedly a world war between a besieged humanity and a superior alien civilization, but players spend most of the time roaming around engaging random clumps of indigenous bandits, mining for resources, and killing mutated fauna. There is a lack of sense about the relevancy or urgency of the war.

Leveling mechanics, itemization, crafting, and questing systems are conventional and unremarkable. Narratives conveyed in missions are discontinuous, because the missions themselves are randomly sequenced. The encounter system is simplistic: most scenarios reduce to close-range engagements as enemies materialize into existence near you. Enemy AI is mediocre: No squad tactics, no flanking, no suppression, no cover. Combat is mostly reduced to jumping and backpedaling away from enemies. It becomes less about surviving enemies, and more about surviving the point-blank splash damage from your own weapons.

Play it for the eye candy and esthetics, and for the easy adrenaline. Look elsewhere for more filling and better execution. Intelligently challenging PVE battles, cohesive narratives, and a world story that invites urgency elude Firefall at this time.

reviewText:
A lot of the thoughts in the negative reviews are 100% correct - This is sub-standard MMO, questing fare. Get the quest, walk, collect or kill, return, repeat.

However, there's something to it. The multiple abilities, the various characters, the movement with jump-packs. There is something here.

I thorougly loved Borderlands, and there are striking similarities (a bit too similar in parts), but this game certainly has the base for something bigger. I'm only level 8 at the moment, but will certainly be making it to 40, and putting some money into the game for the XP boosts.

I'm conflicted, but I'm having fun.

reviewText:
Review and tips focused towards new players, i am a beta player with over 2 years test experience in this title.
----

First off, you need to know that this 3rd person shooter is also a MMO experience, so keep in mind you need to grind levels and components, a lot of time is needed to play this game, and with how the system works (and a good point i might add) is that you cant just sit there and leech from other people, you physically need to participate to gain XP and credit. So be prepared for a long-lasting (but awesome) experience so long as youre someone who enjoys actually playing the game and not just ya know..sat leeching from someone or not giving a crap.

***Gameplay: 7 / 10
The content is good, the single player missions are good, the different variations of World events and randomly generated content work great! The only problem is, there's not enough different types of mission and it can quickly become repetetive, which goes the same for story missions, theyre enjoyable but there just isnt enough of them (yet). I highly recommend playing with friends especially if they can give you a ride, or (i highly advise) you puchase with Red Beans of ingame Credits, a BIKE. Without a vehicle this game is a looong walk simulator, but as soon as you get a vehicle and craft yourself a lot of 1-use glider pads this mobility problem goes away (it sorta forces you to get a vehicle, but thats ok they need to make money somehow to sustain these big servers).
PvE Content is very well balanced and challenging, if you charge into a base full of bandits or chosen at your level, expect to get yourself killed very quickly as especially the Chosen, are a force to be reconned with. PvP is promising but ultimately, there's no balance and its only fun for the few. The classes you are allowed to play cover all the basic roles (tank, support, healer, dps etc) and the advanced battleframes (which i recommend Bastion, Dragonfly/Recluse, Raptor/Nighthawk or Mammoth for new players as these currently seem the most powerful) grant even further power to your class.
They have confirmed, and are adding a lot of content in the future including a level cap rise with (confirmed) at least 2 new world-zones, so expect a LOT of good things for this free-to-play title.

***Sound: 7 / 10
The music feels very gripping with its orchestral quality and all weapons sounds great, you really feel the oomph of your weaponry and explosions from afar you can almost feel the vibrations from. Sound quality is excellent! Though the roaming music can sorta make you a bit sleepy. The musical score is wonderful in missions and cutscenes but the roaming music is too boring. The game's vocal content and all NPC's (and quest givers) is about 97% fully voice acted! Some of those accents though are not very well spoken, and may sounds a bit cheesy, several of the voice actors seem uninterested but overall, sound is good.

***Graphics and worlds: 5 / 10
The maps look average and the systems overal graphics are well toned (character style inspired from Street Fighter 4). I wouldnt call firefall next-gen, its sorta in between last gen and next gen. It's optimized enough to run smoothly including in huge fights of 40 players and a hundred enemies at once on the screen (which is amaaaaziiiiing) but GPU Temperatures can run a little high so i highly recommend turning a few things down (shadows low or off, and antialiasing off unless your computer is an icecube). The worlds although they looks pretty, (gunna be honest here) will p### you off, as every obstacle, every mountain with no climbable surface, every tree/rock/nook and granny and just how lumpy the ground is, seems to do its utmost best to slow you down and hinder your ability to go someplace, which is why they sell glider-pads in game to make money off of you. Because of the terrible pathing in maps and how it fights and pushes you to the point of frustration when youre trying to be in a rush to go someplace, it heavily impacts this rating. The maps by design are agonizing.

***Overall: 7 / 10
There's a lot of potential here, keep in mind you DO have to spend some money if you want to get anywhere near end-game here because of long distance traveling and the advanced battleframes being stronger (mostly), but with the extra content coming, the community being really supportive of Firefall, and the playerbase being really co-operative and nice in game, i highly recommend this title.
Remember, it's free-to-play, but if you want to get serious about this game, you will need to spend a little money OR, spend a lot of time. Recommended: Get a vehicle, unlock the class you really want to play, tryout a 100% XP boost to get out of the first 10 boring levels and BOOM! You got yourself a really fun game, with great PvE experiences, and a solid future.

This game was so good in closed and open beta, my account is 4,5 years old created December 14, 2011 03:57, I figured I'd give the game a try again but wtf, it's just a empty shell, lackluster and just plain boring, I regret spending so much money on this game during closed beta and the beginning of open beta when it was still fun.

reviewText:
A study in game design theory, Firefall is a title that is fantastic on paper and mediocre in practice.  Most of what's present is forgivable, but the primary attraction is ultimately its biggest liablity.  Ultimately, it won't appeal to MMO fans due to it's watered down questing and pve mechanics, and action fans will dismiss it due to a lack of refinement.

Firefall's story revolves around the discovery of meterological elements that allow us to build fantastic technology, such as jet pack suits, advanced weapons, and space ships.  The goal of traveling to an Earth like planet is foiled by further plot mechanics, as the ship crashes into Earth, rendering most of the surface uninhabitable.  The obligitory aggressive alien species comes to Earth to take over, and this sets the stage for blah blah blah.

Poorly written sci fi tropes doesn't compel a player to continue on with the story, so the game heavily relies on the action elements.  These are where the biggest problems manifest, because the actual meat of the game is mediocre at best.  The game has a one to one action component, which is unusual for MMO's as it's a genre that caters to point and click, but Firefall tries desperately to stand out.  Instead it feels like a mechanically stripped down shooter with very little to differentiate itself from the hundreds of other FPS games, and strapping a jet pack to your character does very little to help.

The actual physics of flying feel so static and boring that it really shouldn't have bothered.  Instead of using it as a method to travel quickly from place to place, it simply allows for altitude adjustments, and has very little “skiing”, something that the tribes games were lauded for.  Strategically, it's still important for melee centric enemies as you'll jet above them and shoot as they attempt with great futility to nibble your ankles.  If an inertial effect was added to the jetting the game would be a pleasure, especially with the varied terrain.  As is, moving from point A to B in the game is a chore.

Production values crush what enjoyment could have been gleaned from the rest of this game, as the graphics, sound, interface, and general design are adequate, but that's it.  The view distance for terrain, monsters and allies is good, but up close they look pretty meh.  This is in no small part due to an unusual cartoonish design, somewhere between Borderlands and World of Warcraft, but nowhere near as endearing as either.  It comes off as generic and unexciting, with little if anything unique about it.  Enemy design suffers the most, as it isn't just dull, it only has a handful of variations.  In about 3 hours of gameplay, I had seen the same arachnid design used for about half the enemies, and zombie like enemy soldier for the other.  From the sound of a machine gun to rockets firing, to my commander speaking to the lowly civilians, everything sounds awful.  The voice acting especially is cringe worthy, with the theater commander taking the prize for most obnoxious line delivery this year.

Potential is squandered on a regular basis in the gaming industry, but rarely had expectations been so high; a 1 to 1 action mmo with jetpacks, a pvp component, and a free to play model.  All that's left is an excellent case study in how design doesn't necessarily equate to execution.  Firefall isn't terrible, it's just a really basic, stripped down action game that just happens to have an MMO component tacked on.  Both are incredibly basic and unrefined, and leaves very little to entice fans of either genre.  In the end, it really isn't worth your time unless major improvements are made.

reviewText: Ignore the older just-after-release reviews. Yes this game had a rocky start, yes it didn't deliver right away and yes it used to be very buggy. But the team shows true love for their game and has been constantly upping the ante and making this a game that gets more and more fun. I think the developers are doing a truly admirable job turning this game around and delivering a very satisfying and addictive game. The free to play concept is worked out quite honestly while at the same time leaves some room to splurge on a few nice extra's. Just walking around, enjoying the scenery, questing and chasing random events is a fun, and if done properly, fast way to build a few nice characters. Atmosphere is great and as a busy man with not too much free time this is a really nice way to spend a few hours once in a while. Good graphics too and runs smoothly on a proper PC.\n\nJust simply put, one of the better FTP games on steam and I'm glad to see the community is getting on the bandwagon because this game deserves it! The special events are a blast btw!

reviewText:
Don't bother. This game has been reworked about four times now. Even after kicking that idiot Mark Kern to the curb, development still has absolutely no direction whatsoever.

Most of the balance changes are actually decent. However, this latest update disabled a lot of features because suprise, they're being reworked. For the fifth time. Also, end game zones? Being reworked as well, so good luck finding stuff to do at max level, especially since thumping is no longer fun in the slightest.

For those who played before, remember the arsenal frame? It had pretty decent firepower with its LMG, and abilities granted weapons with limited ammo to be used in certain situations. A shotgun with high damage, a particle beam for long range AOE, and so on. Its ultimate was great, my favorite one in the game. Ever see Macross? The mechs which could fire off a ton of missiles at once? Basically that, though the rockets here arc like mortar fire. And it was AWESOME!

Sounds like a cool frame, right? Well, it's gone. Just removed completely because the developers are too stupid to figure out how to bolster its shortcomings. And not one single frack was given when people who loved it clamored for it back. They did offer pretty nice compensation, but as cool as the vehicle is, I'd rather have my Arsenal back.

Save your time and energy for something else. This game could have been wonderful, but they spent far too much time just figuring out what they wanted this game to be... and still are!

If you must try, I'd recommend not spending any real money. Let's face it, the game and Red5 are on its last legs. I'm actually surprised it's lasted this long, especially after its abysmal failure in Asia. I really don't think they'll make it to the end of 2016.

Need to get your shooter fix? There are plenty of better offerings on Steam. Go try one of those, and leave this game to die.

BTW my play time was mostly using the proprietary launcher, not Steam. So ♥♥♥♥ off with hours played BS.

reviewText:
This is going to be a short and to the point review, so forgive the lack of flattery or filler.

This game has been holding onto life by some force I don't even recognize, to be honest.
I played this game back in closed beta and it was amazing and new to me. Given it didn't have much content, but it was always updating and the story was opening up. I would've given the game a 7.5/10 score.
It's been a long time now and I have played a good chunk of time again, and I am sorely disappointed.
* It's full of bugs and glitches that aren't typically fixed. Some are, most are not.
* Updates don't always fix what's broken and they include what the community has called 'Ninja Updates' that they intentionally hide so as to try and avoid confrontation from their playerbase.
* A game once made to reward skill and strategy is now just Who can do the more AoE damage". Skill is no longer a thing. The deadliest and most used classes are AoE classes
date:
aside from Dragonfly healers of course.
* PvP is more or less dead. Now the PvP zone sees only the occasional battle but is more or less quiet and only for getting materials.
* The game is horribly optimized. Beefy computers can see lag. Amazing connections will still see latency problems.
* The phrase "Don't fix what isn't broken" is often seen in action.

reviewText:
The beta builds for Firefall in 2012 were so much better than this current build, and by that I mean around Aug/Sept/Oct time; cuase I didn't really get to play the beta as much as I would have, since something happened to my client, it's wouldn't run or even uninstall. I didn't get to play Firefall again till it was on steam a week or so ago.

They took most, if not all, the fun out of this game. The areas are level based now, I remember being able to roam the whole map just about. The random events are gone as far as I can see. No more invasions by the melting or chosen, I remember watchtowers being attacked all the time, and random invasions here and there; don't see any happening now. The crashed thumpers and LGV's are still here, but seem to be fewer than before to me.

Then there's the crafting and reaserch. There wasn't any research when I was playing beta. I don't mind it, but they put in TOO much; it needs to be combined and have AT LEAST 50% of it cut out. Either that or make a lot of other ways to get reaserch points other than savalaging, or reduce the points costs as well. And what happened to all the minerals? There's nothing but sand/dirt and iron now that I found around the starting area, there used to be at least a third mineral too around the starting area.

I also remember a horizontal skill/gear/weapon tree that you got a point (or whatever) to spend on every level up for a frame; that was option based, as in every level of the tree had at least two choices (such as between two weapons, a weapon or skill, booster/gear item or something else, and etc.) and you could always wait another level to get the second (or other choices) if you wanted both (or all). There was also a particular upgrade" path to advanced frame 1 or advanced frame 2

reviewText:
What can I say that would ease the pain? That it was great while it lasted? Those are the words that should be said for an awesome game that's closing its doors for the final time; celebrations of the life of a community and good game that ran for well over a decade. I had a few of these experiences. Phantasy Star Online for example was one of these, (the first one mind you. There's still Private Servers, but no point since PSO2 exists). I played a few other little MMOs here and there in my youth. In 2012, I found this awesome game called FireFall, and fell completely in love with it. It had the makings for an awesome story, awesome gameplay/gunplay, it was an MMO and an FPS combined... and something like this was new to me. Hell, it was one of the firsts... by which I mean if I point my gun at something and pull the trigger, it dies. No tab-targeting to be seen.

I was a founding Commander too even. Watched the game grow during the early days of beta. You could go anywhere in the world, you could shoot whatever moved... there was actual things to do. Pretty sandbox-y for those early days. I remember spending a couple good years with this one group... well, several groups actually, although with this one community army, I could never really get into it offically... so I just operated as an outside agent. It was the game that got me to buy my first graphics card since I wasn't really big on the PC market back then... so I can thank Firefall for that. The other group, we had a teamspeak and good times. Sure it was a little rough... but I'm generally pretty chill. Good times were had, before that got broke up; this of course being after everyone else had quit... the game became stagnant due to a MAJOR flaw; the developers at Red5 Studios were rebuilding the game from the ground-up, so that left us with little-to-no updates outside of hotfixes. They'd started this whole entire promotional bit with a bus (which is sitting in a warehouse somewhere now), prizes to be given out for their Founder Packs (which were available for a good year or so), and no actual NEW content. No new guns or gun designs, no new Battleframes; nothing.

Then comes a new update that kills PvP off (which was fine for me since I didn't play it anyway), which was pretty lackluster to begin with... adds some new zones to teleport to which didn't let you go very far. They rebuilt crafting, and progression to a near-unplayable level. For example.... you could have this really nice Tier 3 Plasma Cannon (Assault), but then you can't get anything else.. abilities, armor, servos... nothing. Or you could kit out your plating and become a little bit better than paper mache (READ: tinfoil), but then you couldn't kit out anything else because of constraints. Math went in and between a few people collabing together, they figured out it'd take 13.5 years to max out.... one Battleframe. ONE. Not all 15... just one.

Well, come later on and after enough hell-raising, instead of fixing the stupidly-high progression requirement ceiling (they reduced it a little bit but not by much), they spend more time with their Twitch streams and social garbage such as Red 5 TV... and rebuild the game yet a second time. More waiting... more time spent... and still as friends left, I stuck with it. I stuck by them... and little did we know that Red 5 was pretty turbulent internally; all the senior staff had been fired off at this point, The9 which was the people funding Red 5 at this point had a complete strangle-hold on them at this point, and returns were being requested. They booted out Mark Kern... one of the main CEOs of Red 5 (READ: the guy who FOUNDED Red 5 in the FIRST place!!), and hired another guy to lead development for a little while.

Progress got quicker, and then Open Beta hits... after 2½ years it finally hits and people are estatic. They added a new Battleframe which was pretty cool... until I figured out how bad it was. It was called Arsenal" which was this hulking Frankenstein-esque junk frame thrown together from various other frame abilities and parts
recommended: and carried a pretty poor LMG with did crap-all to anything you shot at.. and its abilities were poor imitations of other weapons which didn't even last but a few seconds
hoursPlayed: a butchered Engineer "Salvo Proxy" called some sort of new lame ability and made its ultimate. That's right... ultimates replaced the fourth ability... which had turned this game's skill system into that of a damn MOBA's abilities (three boring abilities

reviewText:
Firefall is a open-world game that is fun for the first several hours, but then gets repetitive as there is not a whole lot to do besides begin leveling the upgraded counterpart after getting max rank. The game starts you off landing on copacobana, a resort town surrounded by a beach on one side and a forest on the other. You have multiple battleframes to choose from to suit your play style, such as the assault, recon, or the engineer. With each battleframe you get to max level you can unlock a advanced frame that sports new abilities and access to a new primary weapon.
The world allows you to reach max level without touching a job board do to the abunance of ares missions that are scattered around the map. They will give you as much if not more experience than doing a job board mission in a fraction of the time, however the game is a huge grindfest and gets downright aggravating at times.
The gameplay is alot like a watered down borderlands mixed with warframe. You fight dangerous wildlife, rouge bandits, and the infamous chosen which is humanitys main foe. There is not a whole lot to do in the game besides grind, grind, and grind some more.  After leveling my second battleframe I tried yet again to begin leveling another battleframe, but i couldn't bring myself to go through the tedious grind for a third time.
When i was reading chat, every now and then the conversation would lean toward talking about the beta and how great it was compared to the way it is now. I did not have the chance to play the beta, but then i think i would be even more dissapointed in the game like so many others who have played and reviewed this game. It is very repetive, lacks content, and is honestly a snoozefest that couldn't keep my interest. Save yourself the time and the hard drive space for something better than Firefall.

reviewText: I was a founder for this game years ago back when it was a mmo shooter with rpg elements and an expansive crafting system. I took some time off to deal with life things only to come back to a game that lost most of its shooter elements to be replaced by meaningless rpg fodder and a handicapped crafting system. The game as it stands is a grinder with little redeemable qualities. You will empty entire clips into one enemy. You will traverse long distances to redo the same quest. And calldowns no longer work correctly.\n\nI think everyone should take the time to play this game for a few hours. It has its charms but should serve more as a museum piece for what the industry could be doing. Imagine that when I played this game religiously I was one soldier in a massive war spanning the entire Copacobana region with Chosen attacking all sectors. It was a fight where people in the chat had to determine on the fly what we would hold and what we would let fall due to manpower constraints. As a Recon, I held off Chosen at the Thump Dump Watchtower for half an hour until enough reinforcements could arrive. It reminded me of the glory of Tabula Rasa. Now you can sprint through all these areas with near impunity. There is no war. There is only the grind.

reviewText:
Firefall is a real shooter. I've played a lot of other MMOs out there that have an open world, and generally they tend to just be variations of tab targeting games, Planetside being the only other active MMO that also plays like a real shooter in my experience, but it's all PvP.
Firefall lets you out in a large world, with lots of creatures to kill, various tasks to complete, multiple frames to unlock and advance, in general it just has a lot of stuff to do in and is for the most part it's quite fun while doing those things.

I've been around for a long time back with the old closed beta and have seen Firefall change over time, it's had it's ups and downs, and some very slow progress was made for much of that time. More recently however that seems to have changed and Firefall has found it's direction and is solidly making progress down this path. So, for everyone who knows the horror stories of the forever in development game, give it another shot, you'll probably be pleasantly surprised.

If you're new and just looking for a fun game to play, well you'll definitly find Firefall to be a good choice. It's free, it lets you explore and epic world and engage in some large fights, and there's no real pay to win going on so you don't have anything to lose giving it a try except a little time and bandwidth. And with all that you might gain...

reviewText: I've been playing this game for 3 years now in Closed/Open beta.  It's gone though many changes but ultimately I feel that this game breaks the mold between shooter and massively multiplayer online games out there.  It combines both genres into something unique.  The world is visually stunning with a soundtrack to match.  Your ultimate goal is to gather resources and fight off Chosen, an alien race who are invading the Earth.  Humanity is on the brink of extinction from a death fog known as the Melding.  This melding works as a device for unlocking new areas and fighting back for territory control.  Anyways, you can play many Battleframes (exoskeleton suits) and upgrade them all, all having unique special weapons and combat styles.  It's not like a typical MMO in which you have specific classes, each is able to hold their own ground and do it all... granted you have the skill!  Check it out, it's free to play and will never offer a P2W advantage.

reviewText:
Firefall left me with an excellent first impression, and I reveled in it with a small group of my friends for a week.
It presented itself with immersive gameplay, as it offered a open world atmosphere, fantastic random encounters across the map, and a voiced operator that guided you along your quests.
The combat was a bit bland and minimalistic, but was decent for an MMO shooter, and allowed for a swift learning experience. Team cooperation for random encounters and bosses was encouraged, and a PvE environment allowed a friendly, and helpful community to thrive.
The premium currency in this game is a wonderful thing to have to quicken the rate in which you advanced through the game, but wasn't a necessity.
The art style didn't knock my socks off, but it worked with their futuristic, yet sort of leisurely, and laid-back feel of the environment. It was in a Post-Apocalyptic scenario, so I wish the game's storyline would cohere with a darker, more serious tone, to prevent the game from looking like a Paradise Paintball" a bunch of pre-teens would play.

What disappointed me
date: and led to the desertion of this game that I once thoroughly enjoyed
recommended: was the lack of apparent progression. The developers seemed to have forgotten to polish some key aspects of MMO's that made them fun. Levels
hoursPlayed: new abilities
voteText: and gear did not provide any distinct differences in playstyle
helpfulPercent: and offered little pleasure in using.\nThe game unfortunately ended up in a grind
votesHelpful: with run-of-the-mill quests that rewarded you with a whole lot of dissatisfaction. I wanted to keep in touch with the game
votesTotal: by waiting for new content
votesFunny: but by that time
commentsCount: my friends were already bored
column16: and subsequently abandoned the game.\n\n4/10. I'd recommend this game to those with a couple friends that want to fool around for a while
column17: but is not a game you should invest a lot of time or money in.\nWarframe fits the same Free-To-Play
column18: Sci-Fi niche
column19: and offers a better arsenal of weapons and classes.\n"

reviewText: If the veterans of this game out there enjoyed any part of it before, then don't buy the early access. Everything that made this game unique and fun has been deleted so that they could make Standard MMO: Guns Edition. They killed the crafting system, killed the incentive to get new gear from non-quest sources, killed the leveling system, killed the dynamic world, killed the auction house, and killed the freedom of choice that made this game so good. If you want to play a completely generic MMO, play one with more content. If you want to shoot stuff, then pick up a shooter game. It's plain and simple.

reviewText: (2 years of play, hundreds of hours spent ingame)\nI must say I really liked what this game initially promised, horizontal shooter where skill matters. Sandbox activities that would shape the world, epic and fun events that would generate dynamically. Well NOPE, that's not where game ended up. After numerous internal turmoils game wasn't progressing properly, huge amounts of work were thrown away and what did make it into the game made little sense, added little value and was terribly broken for months. And now it's releasing as fairly regular MMORPG treadmill with some shooter aspects, but with vertical progression, repetitive predictable activities and overall boring experience. Most popular features are ones where players abuse game mechanics to skip through game progression. That means standing on one spot for 24 hours a day gaining XP for doing nothing, mindlessly shooting at everything or just placing automated turrets ... Known as AFK DH Ares, AFK Thumping, XP Valley and so on.

reviewText:
The moment you play this game, they quickly try to get your immersed in their universe by getting you to jump straight into their story campaign. The game then quickly gives you insight to each class and have you choose one to begin the campaign. Despite giving brief desciption, you do get a sense of lost on how truely worth wild some weapons/class are more than others. In most cases, I ended up using the AOE type gun because the mobs move around so fast and I'm spinning around looking for them because they might be going after your buddies or some stranger behind you then at the bottom of your feet, you got alien roaches poking you and you don't really know until they hit you because they are small and jump at random targets sometime. Being ammo based(you can replenish it with several ways), if you're not accurately skilled at aimming, you could be ending up wasting a lot of ammo. A lot of times when I shoot monsters, the whole feel of it doesn't feel right because I shoot, they stop, twitch then die and I'm standing there wondering wtf just happened.

In one quest I had to go blow up some reactors or something in some enemy base? Base is empty, I freely walked through, then random enemies spawned that I quickly took out. SO BORING. Killing Hogger was more fun.

Customizing your character is a bit lack luster, I wasn't impressed at the choices they offered. Their guns, although look different when compared to the next, didn't give that same feel like when you play other games like WoW. Getting stuff like a Thunderfury even though its subpar when compared to higher tier items like warglaives, is still a great vanity and awesome weapon to have around. Firefall, to me, all weapons look and feel the same to an extent or using the same template thats altered for unique-ness sake.

Didn't understand upgrading much either and I got lost pretty easily. Because its so open world, you can get lost pretty fast when you're new or just traveling is a chore unless you use the glider. I found myself bumping into things way more than I would like. With other MMO, despite being less opened, players aren't likely to get lost or get caught somewhere like between two rocks under a hut and is not quite stuck yet not loose enough to get free. With enough patience, you could find fast routes.

The quest though important for certain game mechanics, seems pointless and falls off the cliff of being side tracked. Placed me in an important military group only to make me run dumb errands like finding someone's husband? Hello?! I'm a elite warrior thats going to save humanity! Ain't nobody got time for this sheez! I didn't bother reading nor care what I was getting. I didn't understand the point at all.

I felt very lost, out of placed and out of context when it comes to syngery or immersion in this huge epic story to save humanity. Didn't make me want to play more to unlock stuff. For a FPS type MMOG, I don't know how well it'll do. If any of you played Tabula Rasa, I felt more immersed into that game than this one and you had to walk everywhere... EVERYWHERE! Too bad it had some short comings it didn't fix in time.

Hopefully Firefall gets back on track. There's some pretty embarasing and funny bugs and glitches that im surprised they didn't fix. As of now, I'm lost, bored, not caring much about the main/side story. Looking at the battleframes and such, I don't think my time will be of any worth investing either. It's a shame. Being how old WoW is, I still considered it one of the top tier games atm and they executed it very well. Only reason it's not as popular now is because people want something fresh. Some might contest because they like their FREE MMO". Nothing tops SWG
date: pre Combat Patch. Give it to SOE for screwing up an amazing game like that."

reviewText:
To the people reviewing the game: you are reviewing THIS BUILD, not the beta previously.

Having played since CBT I can safely say that this is the Firefall we were promised so many E3s ago. They finally gave up on the silly esports and pseudo-EVE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and decided that if they wanted to be a fun shooter MMO they should just focus on being a fun shooter and a fun MMO- and Firefall is both. The beta builds were infamous for being a boring, repetitive grindfest but the public release is the exact opposite. It feels more like playing an open-ended campaign from start to finish than a traditional MMO. The equipment is simple but you have a lot of control over your gear. The content is plentiful, varied, and fun. The art is astonishing, and makes the game very easy on the eyes.

If you ever wanted a Borderlands-style MMO, this is what you've been waiting for.

Don't buy the negativity, try it for yourself. People have every right to be bitter, but not to lie about the state of the game.

reviewText:
I'll make this quick

PROS
- fluid movement
- unique environments
- not necessarily P2W
- Fun with friends
- Unique leveling system

CONS
-REPETITIVE gameplay
-Long and Unnecessary grinding
- you MUST unlock story missions
- Weapons all look the same
- few enemy types
- many Bugs

By all means try the game and form your own opinion. The game doesn't feel finished or very unique in any way besides the environments. You spent the majority of your time doing the same few sets of side missions until you level enough to complete a story mission, then new side missions come and you repeat the process. The weapons all look the same and there are only 4 player abilities per class. You don't feel like your working towards much in the game besides progressing through the story. Like i said before, try the game and form your OWN opinion, I mean hey, you can't go wrong with free stuff. Hopefully the devs make changes to the game to make all the hours of grinding feel worthwhile.

reviewText:
---DEVS, YOU NEED TO FIX THIS ASAP!!!---
1 Heart-broken gamer/10

So... I haven't played this game in a long while. But when I saw the Rocketeer DLC I got hyped about playing the game once more. So I installed the game again and bought several DLC Packs actually. I was really looking forward to playing my awesome Engineer once more.

So I start the game and watch that awesome trailer where this group of ARES Pilots gets attacked by Araneas, amongst other things, while defending their Thumper. The trailer brings back sweet memories of all the awesome combat I've had with my Engineer. The Engineer quickly changes weapons on her wrist-mounted device and kicks ♥♥♥ etc. It's sooo awesome.

So then I eventually get into the game only to find it almost completely redone!! (in my eyes atleast...)
- The story is remade as far as I can tell...

- The equipment/gear is completely changed. The armor looks reaaaally clunky and unbalanced...

- But the most noticable change? I no longer have a wrist-mounted secondary gun.... I hold it in my fri**** hands... why?
The wrist-mounted version was soo awesome.... why change that? That's what made the Engineer stand out from the other classes...

- And the visual design on the Engineer/Bastion isn't even the same as the trailer anymore... that made me reaaaally pi****!... I mean how can you have the original trailer and not have the original visuals on the fri**** Engineer?!

Not happy, not happy at all.... I won't be recommend this game to my friends anymore... not until this bug" gets fixed...
This is like what Blizzard did to WoW all over again.... sigh... why mess up a perfecly good game guys? come on... please... don't take this game away from me too... I used to love this game.... :("

reviewText:
Simply put, this game is absolutely nothing like it used to be. It was fantastic in beta... I played the hell out of it, somewhere in the ballpark of 400 hours or so. Arguably the best MMOFPS I have played to date, and I stopped playing it about three years ago. I spent money on this game, and that is something I never, ever do with free to play titles.

I downloaded it again, tried to give it another shot... I just couldn't do it. It didn't even feel the same. This was after release, and especially after the most game-degrading update made to it since it became available publically. My fears were confirmed. You got greedy. You got lazy.

Congratulations, Red 5 Studios. You not only wasted my time, but yours, and countless others who are also sitting here wondering what the hell you were thinking.

During Closed/Open Beta:  9.5/10

After release: 4/10 (after the lastest update.. Pft. Maybe a 2/10.)

reviewText:
I've been playing FIrefall for a spell now, probably a little more than a month.  I was looking for a fun RPG to play, and came across it browsing Steam.  I have enjoyed this game immensely, getting to know the crafting, jobs, instances, and world events.

Firefall has a lot of different stuff to do, though as many other reviews bring up, sometimes it can get a bit grindy(what with 16 or so frames to level).  That being said, there's a decent community on Firefall, and it's a lot of fun to run with other people in a squad, really letting you see the different classes work together.  The Types(classes) all feel different, and the Advanced Frames have some pretty fun changes, such as the Mammoth's ability to teleport, or the Raptor's Powerfield.

It's not perfect, sometimes the job boards can take a while to load objectives, and sometimes the UI doesn't work.  While it might not be the best to say at least they have a quickfix(/rui) that usually corrects it... but hey, at least there's that.  The devs are still active, working on game systems and fixing issues as they can.  In fact, I even have gotten the chance to go on a run with a dev, which was super neato.

All in all, I've really enjoyed this game's feel, from the combat which can often be intense and fast-paced, the myriad of events going on, and the variety of ways to play with the different Types and Frames.  Oh, and it's all voice acted, from all the job boards to the Campaign instances.

Looking for something fun and free, give Firefall a try :)

reviewText: FireFall is a open world MMO first and third person shooter what is skill based. All fighting in the game, be it PVE or PVP, is all 3 dimensional as every player have jumpjets and different enemies fly or hide underground. Each archtype (class) of battleframes plays differently from each other and can accommodate a large variety of different playing styles. You can easlies be the long wolf or the leader of an army. The would is alive as missions and randomed events can happen anywhere at anytime, because of this you are always going into the unknown when traveling or fighting.\n\nThere many stories to be told and found thoughout the world. Just because it seems like the end of the world people are not going to stop being people. The personal lifes and drama people have to deal with day to day just doesn't go away because the looming threat that everyone be killed at a moment's notice. Help out survivors learn their stories and maybe learn more about what is happen behind the scenes.

reviewText:
The world of firefall is really interesting and beautifully designed. However that is all this game has going for it atm.
I played this game a year ago and quit because it had nothing to do outside of senseless grinding (you grinded for items to help you when you grind. There was no real goal in the game and nothing grinding took you too unless it was to level up your battle frames for a new battleframe). Came back to it today and was introduced to a large amount of major bugs that completely ruined the game for me already.


Bugs i've encountered from today:
-Key commands randomly stop working, only way to fix this is to relog your character. Sometimes the esc menu key command stops working and you have to force close the client to exit the game... (this bug alone makes the game not worth playing, its a bug that seems to happen frequently)

-Items fall through the map, some quests require you to pick up and transport items, if you throw them (which you have to sometimes if you need to pull out your gun to defend yourself) the items will sometimes fall through the map forcing you to either restart or give up the quest.

-Quests dont work, (for some reason they believed that the quests in the game should not be a part of the client folders when you download firefall. Instead every quest has to load from their servers each time you want to do one, and it doesnt even load the whole quest at once, it loads a part of it then waits till you finish the loaded part till it will start downloading the next part. The problem is at times it will get stuck loading" and prevent you from continuing on in the quest.

-Uncontrolled enemy spawns (not a bug just a dumb decision by the devs). Enemies can spawn infinitely from spawn pods resulting in 50+ enemies piled together in areas. The only way to get rid of them is to kill the them all. The only way to kill them all is with a group of people (good luck with that though since this game has a population of 20 if feels like) or you have to be 10-20 levels higher than the enemies.



I want this game to succeed i'm sure a lot of people do but i really doubt it will. They added new content
date: i havnt tried it yet. But the amount of bugs i encountered from 1 day of playing has already made me hate this game again.\n\nMaybe in another year if this game can somehow survive
recommended:
it might be worth looking at. For now you can have a lot more fun elsewhere.


"

reviewText: If you like third person shooters you should most definetly give this a try. Its not a deep game with lots of intricate game play and deep stats. What it is though is a heck of a lot of fun to play. Jump in and go guns blazing. You can play for hours jumping from thing to thing but its also very easy to get in and play for little snippets since most events are only 5-10 minutes long. And Jet Packs. . . who doesn't love Jet Packs?! I keep waiting to get tired of them and just don't. I think many will disagree with me but I also find the game to be very well optimized. I can be on screen with about 20-30 other players and at 30-50 mobs with all sorts of abilites and effects going off and have very little FPS drop. The game is able to dynamically downgrade your quality to keep FPS up which is a nice feature. It could be that it is not that well optimized and its this feature kicking in that does the trick, but honestly, I'm not focused on textures when I am hopping around like mad trying to blast baddies.\n\nIts also a pretty good F2P model. You can reasonably get everything you want in game given enough time, and the time spent isn't even that egregious. The main things people will want in the store are new frames and transportation. The frames can be obtained by leveing one of the free frames which gives you the ability to unlock a new one for free and so on. The transportation is really something you need to spend money on. You can get a free LGV (motor cycle) at level 25 but thats a pretty long way in and single use gliders will just get frustrating. The company has to make money somewhere so I think this is a good trade off. The other thing to buy is cosmetic stuff but that in no way is required and is just fluff.

reviewText:
The name is accurate now, for it fell, and it is most certainly burning.

Ignore my hours, as I actually have played this game off-steam.

Firefall is a game that has been plagued with bad decisions for some time now. Almost as long as it's been losing players, in fact. Slowly, but steadily, the game shifted from amazing me with its quality, to instead amazing me with just how terrible the devs could prove themselves to be. It's kind of like most shows on TV these days, with the only exception being that you don't come in with the expectation of it being terrible from the get-go.

With the most recent update, the game finally stopped clinging onto mixed-quality limbo and dropped into the flaming pit of no return, screaming in agony with Electronic Arts, Activision, Ubisoft, Aeria Games, Nexon, and Perfect World Entertainment. Purchased by a Chinese company, Firefall was pressured into pushing out an update that wasn't even ready, and my goodness was it ever not ready. The update that killed Firefall" as the community calls it
