reviewText:
It sure has been a while in beta now! And we definitely had a lot of ups and downs in all this time.
But I think this (most likely) last iteration on it is by far one of the better, if not the best. Since the game is not released yet, I can only review the beta as it is right now and leave some thoughts on what is planned for launch.

First of all in this MMO you do not have to choose a character, and a class for it that will forever stay with you. Not at all, your character has access to any Battleframe you wish. Well, 5 of them at the start. 11 of them if you purchase them with an ingame currency (called pilot tokens which you get by simply playing the game) or, if you really can't wait, Red Beans which is the real money currency. These Battleframes, the very well thought-out futuristic armors of Firefall, aren't set classes either.
Every Battleframe has access to a big variety of abilities and perks which you can find or unlock to build your favorite Frame around your favorite playstyle.

Second point, it is indeed an open world. Quite an impressive one too. Not only visually but it always has something to do in it.
Now for your freedom of exploring, you might not be able to go anywhere and kill stuff right from the start, but every corner of New Eden, which is the place you will start the game in, has a quite a few things to be discovered while you level up your Battleframe. This does not mean however that you can not just walk anywhere you want! You're free to go to any place you like to your own risk. No portals or gates that will kick you out! But own risk because enemies will get stronger in different parts of the world. Which for the most part shouldn't be a problem however if you play with friends. And the veteran players are always there to help too.

Speaking of the community. So far, it has been one of the best gaming communities I have ever participated in.
Questions will get answered, you will always get revived or supported and everyone is being nice to each other.
Sure there are sometimes exceptions to every one of these points, but they're really rare in Firefall. At least in beta.
Outside of the game there are plenty of fansites and guides from players too.

Well, then there's of course the combat which I should talk about.
I personally never play in first person. Which is why I will just say that I didn't find anything to complain about in the few minutes I played in that perspective. FoV goes up to 120 and everything's pretty fluid.
For third person I have to say that it feels just wonderful, which isn't a surprise considering Firefall had once plans to compete as an esports shooter. The character handles very well, and everything feels really responsive.
Now for the combat itself against the environment. There are a whole lot of enemies with different different abilities and characteristics. Aranhas in example, the spider-like creatures come in many different sizes and ways to kill you. Little, fast sprinters that try to bite off a piece of you, or bigger acid-spewing bugs.  Some even try to explode right in your face!
Then there are of course the main enemies of the game. The Chosen. Even those aren't just the same cloned trooper. Some carry sniper rifle-like weaponry, others whole cannons. Some try to get you close to them, others will take you out from further away.

The story so far is pretty interesting too. It is not only told by campaign missions or little jobs though, throughout New Eden you will find recordings which contain a lot of lore too. It's a good balance between getting the story told to you directly and to find out yourself by exploring the world.

To finish a review that got a lot longer than I expected, let's talk about the favorite topic when it comes to free to play.
Is it pay to win? No. Red5 said they will never sell any power to you. And so far they have never done so and don't seem to ever will. The only advantage" you can get over other players is shorter crafting times or currency boosts in example. Just optional convenience items and cosmetics.
Are you forced to pay to get anything out of the game without grinding for years? Well here's a point where it's pretty much opinion versus opinion. You see
date: it is an MMO. The grind will always be there to some degree. But trust me
recommended: it is and will become way less of a grind and more of an adventure to you to level up. Not only that
hoursPlayed: but you can always do whatever you feel like

reviewText:
If you've ever played an MMO and wished that it was a little more like Borderlands, or if you've ever played Borderlands and wished that it was more than superficially similar to an MMO, you should give Firefall a shot.

I have been playing Firefall since early beta, and it is constantly imrpoving at a steady pace. I have always enjoyed basically any blend of First-Person Shooter and Role Playing game, so I approach this with a heavy bias.

The main story is actually pretty engaging in a big space opera, future of the entire species kind of way. The side-quests are... on the whole, less like that, but some of them still manage to deliver in terms of ineresting and attention grabbing story. Some (but not all) of the voice acting is so bad that it's funny. Similarly to the queastionable writing, this mostly affects side-missions, but since these can be a very quick way to level, it's not like this stuff is stashed out of the way where the player might never hear it. In spite of being a hammed up cliche(at times), the story is consistent within the game world, and at no point do I find myself wondering why I'm doing anything.

The open world PVP is excellent, but sadly the OWPVP zone tends to be a bit of a ghost town. Every time I've been there I've spent long amounts of time wondering where everyone was only to be quickly ganked and ambushed by the first person I see, who then disappears as suddenly as they appeared. I see potential here, but I can't really tell you what kind of potential since all of my experiences in PVP land have been strange and surreal.

The F2P is not P2W. You advance at a decent rate even if you insist on spending no money on the game. IRL currency can be used to buy basically anything that good old fashioned mining and grinding will get you, but it can also be used to purchase things that make the overall game experience much more convenient (vehicles and gliders, XP and money boosts) or lively (customizations and cosmetics) without giving paying players any sort of advantage over other players (no weapons or kit that only paying players get).

If FPS isn't your thing you can play it in third person.

It's space opera.

The jump jets are just like the ones in Tribes (old Tribes, not the new garbage the kids are playing now, though they're probably just liek the ones in there too, if the new tribes even has jumpjets... can you really do tribes without jumpjets? God I hope they didn't try to do that).

Dude yeah, it's actually just like Tribes and Borderlands had a little F2P MMO baby that bears a strange resemblance to Destiny, but doesn't have Bungie's weird pretentious stench all over it (and it's actually a little less of a grind... yeah, a F2P game is less grindy than B2P Destiny... not sure which game that says more about).

If you read this far just download it already.

reviewText: The fact it can run on a PC as bad as mine with medium quality and still look beautiful gives it a graphics rating of 10 of 10 in my opinion. I have been a Firefall player since the first days of closed beta. Anyone that tries it now wont believe that back then there was only missions, thumping (the resource gathering), and invasions/watchtower fights. They have furthered the experience one can have on Firefall through a Campaign that I give 9.5 out of 10.  The adding of leveled npcs and the leveling of battleframes will take some getting used to for me but hey, its still fun.  I highly recommend this to any serious PvE player. The NPCs get a 10/10 despite the glitches (which make it 10/10 because they are almost always hilarious). The developers of the game often play alongside the players and I have the honor of having two said developers on my friends list. Overall I give this game 9.7/10 for enjoyable campaign, fun PvE combat, seasonal events, the motorcycles (known to us Firefall gamers as LGVs), and the like. Also one more note: Have your friend(s) play with you for a more enjoyable experience. I am normally a lone wolf" on some games

reviewText:
So this is my own personal review/feedback/whatever on Firefall as it stands right now at release. At the time of writing this, I have clocked 500 hours on the release version of Firefall, along with 62 days since it went. It’s based on my last few weeks playing, levelling lower frames from New Eden and beyond, taking on Titan bosses, campaign, etc, etc. Feel free to leave your thoughts or replies here, but like I said, this is my opinion on the game, yours may differ.

Review was written 9th August 2014, Firefall build V1.0.1793.

Story 6/10

The story and lore behind Firefall is really quite good. It’s not just your standard end of the world survival or fantasy game that 90% of the market seems to be flooded with. It’s a great change of pace, the campaign storyline, be it a little short is engaging and I find its biggest issue is the lack of real character development since virtually every character you talk to once or twice, and then never see, or hear of them again. There are a few exceptions to this, like Aero, your operator for example who you will be with your entire Firefall career and Hobbes from the campaign, The Meddler from ARES Jobs but nothing sticks out long enough, or gets enough explanation to make me care about them, their backstory, it just leaves me thinking what a missed opportunity to dive into the Firefall universe. Sure, we don’t need to know about that one random farmer you helped retrieve a bracelet or something, but when it’s a character, really out of the ordinary, like the Meddler for instance, it really would be good to see their backstory.

As you progress in Firefall, the story changes considerably. You start out as a brand new player in town, so you get the low work, collect this, collect that, etc. Once you start to gain the trust of the Accord and fractions though, you are allowed to move on to higher level work, like sensitive data recovery, target elimination. The story really does do an excellent job of keeping you interested in the world, since unlike most characters, Firefall gives you loads of lore, backstory, etc about the world you are living and fighting in. Moving thought the zones, the story is consistent, and gradually builds up from simple tasks to moving on to fight the Chosen in an all-out war with strikes, kidnappings, ambushes, etc.

I am really looking forward to chapter two and beyond for the campaign arcs, if the first one is anything to go by, Firefalls story is only just getting started. Based on what I have seen, I personally rate the story a 6/10. Whilst it is very fun and engaging, the missed opportunity of lack of character development and very short nature of the Campaign overall is a huge downside, once the next chapters come out, I would very much hope I can improve this rating.

Graphics 8/10

One of Firefalls strongest points is its beautiful world. Coral Forest has vast open beaches to rocky cliff faces, to lush forest. Sertao is a rocky desert with dust storms, mountains and small areas of forest more inland. Devils Tusk is on an island covered with lava from erupting volcanos. These are just the zones that players will travel through and they really give the game a sense of vastness and beauty. Playing on Ultra, this game is out of this world.
Firefall has this very unique art style, I can’t quite place my finger on it but it’s like a mix of Manga and Borderlands and to be frank, it’s something that works really well. This game is not designed to be hyper realistic like say Crysis is, but not completely out of the ordinary, like Borderlands goes for.

My only problem is in some places, textures really are stretched out, ruining and scene. There also are quite a few spots where a texture goes into another, and you can clearly see how one is higher resolution compared to the other. Now this could be down to the way Firefall streams in textures as it needs them, as a player with a slow internet connection, I cannot give the game huge bandwidth to download textures, and there is no way to just download them from a launcher or via Steam.

I personally rate the graphics of Firefall to be an 8/10, the only reason I drop marks for it is because in those patches where graphics suck, it just ruins the experience for me. I would like to think in the future, we can see more detailed models, textures, etc being rolled out and any areas where it is a little off can be patched.


Sound 7/10

Firefalls sound when just shooting, running around, etc is average at best. Pretty much every gun of the same variation sounds the same, no matter how good or bad it is, and most sound assets which you hear early on, you will likely hear again, and again, and again.

What really saves the audio for Firefall is its voice acting and its background music. The voice acting for some is really hit and miss, some characters sound really out of place, but overall they do a great job of sucking you into the world, and it’s really nice to see that a AAA MMO went for full voice acted missions, on every job, campaign mission, NPC, etc. For some, this isn’t a huge issue, but for me I really like to have the story read out and brought to life, this is what Firefall does very well.

The background music in Firefall, or its entire OST for that matter is nothing short of amazing. My favourite piece is from the first campaign mission, Crash Down. Sometimes I will want to go and play that mission just to hear that music again and again! I find that even 500 hours in, I love having background music at full volume still, something on many other games I find myself muting due to its repetitive nature or just average music.

I rate the sound of Firefall a 7/10. Whilst many assets are used far too often, the voice acting and the background music and OST I would rate as a 10/10 on their own. Props to the composers and musicians involved in Firefall! On a side note, the OST from buying a starter pack seems to be missing many of the music scores used within Firefall, very disappointing but with a quick search, I’m sure you can turn up the entire music score online.

Continued here: http://forums.firefallthegame.com/community/threads/kuros-review-feedback-of-firefall-1-0.4770821/ Review too long for Steam

reviewText:
Were do i begin, was a big lover of this game, but only before this new update, after a month or three of waiting for them to fix the ability to just log in (yes thats right i could not get past the log on due to been stuck on a loop trying to clam lost battle frames).

After finaly logging in and been able to play the game, I find that I have lost many battle frames(one from each section totaling 5 lost, which equals loads of in game hours playing upgrading etc etc), a loss of all secondary fire for main weapons(except a few that they had to keep), but for some frames/classes you now have lost the one fire method that made the class fun, (IE detonating bombs, posion and many others).  For me these are the big ones, no fun trying to aim at every target, might as well play COD or some other first person shooter...think the devs lost a lot of focus on what they had.

They have also, well looks like... down graded(changed) the graphics in expotions and bullets shooting quality of what looked good, to some form of what is almost comical.

Lost abilityz / equipment that owned.  By the sounds of things items purchased from real money for to own, are now only reanted( not sure on that as haven't played enough to see what will happen and wont be playing much at all).

Devs had a great thing going and was kind of looking forward to new things but they should have made a new game rather than make this one crappy.  maybe in 2020 when the next change happens thay can make it more like the old and I will play again.  why do these game makes take steps bacwards and ignore feedback for a quick buck return is any body guess.   well I guess this leave me with more me time and to find a better game that the garbage they have now created.

Now in saying all that you may love this new version, might be great to play if you never played the old one, there is still some great aspect to the game like jet packs and walking about shooting stuff, but its not even a shaddow of what it could have been in the derection they took...sry devs a big thumbs down from me.

reviewText:
It's a good game to have time to kill until Destiny comes out.

The game is kind of generic, repetitive, and has bunches of fetch quests. There is no unique story to these quests you do, you don't care about any of the characters or whatnot. You just do them for the xp to eventually move onto similar regions. The shooting mechanics are fun and better than Defiance, but still feels a bit floaty compared to other shooters. AND WHAT IS WITH ALL THESE BUGS!? They are 90% of the game's enemies!

If your like me, a hardcore FPS gamer trying to get into MMOs. Don't bother with this game unless your curious. Just stick playing with Destiny when it comes out.

reviewText:
While this is a review in itself, it may contain spoilers/

Introduction:
I have been a Firefall player since back in Closed Beta. The game was never good enough to live up to expectations, of course, this was just in the beta. But, since v1.0 came out for launch, playing in the early access proved that the game has come a long way. Throughout the beta, a lot has been changed, a lot added to the game, and a lot removed, and some even added, made the game worse and then removed(Professions and leveling, gg), but the game took a turn for the best and proves a whole new experience to retain the original story of Firefall.

Free to Play?:
This has been an ongoing conflict. Red 5 claims that Firefall is free to play, and while others may disagree, I agree with Red 5, that this is a truly Free to Play game. A player will never have to spend money to advance/progress/win/play and fully experience. Where there may be some exclusive items(cosmetics, boost, vip, transport) that can only be obtained with the purchase of/with red beans, you won't need these items to fully enjoy the game as most of these items same items can be obtained in game through actually playing the game. Some items that howevever can only be obtained through red beans. Red 5's recent Red Bean exchange fixes that. This is where a person can use in game currency(credits<obtained by trading in crystite) to buy red beans from other players, or sell those players their red beans for credits. In my opinion, this new addition makes firefall a truly Free to play game.

New Player Experience?:
Being in the closed beta for so long got me so accustomed to the UI and the generalfeel of the game. With some parts being far too frustrating and complicated than it needed to be, how it is now, it's far better. While I agree that the research tree could use some more work, UI-wise(actually more complicated than it was before), everything else seems to fit in perfectly in Red 5's(the studio) attempt to make the game easier to understand.

New Content:
From the beta, the game has gotta a lot new content(with more to come I hope). From finally adding the much loved Sertao(the area we saw in early days with dredge), to *TITANS*, yeah i said it, Titans, there's a lot of content to keep someone busy. reviewText:
I've been playing this off and on for 2 years, it took them forever to get out of beta but I gotta say I always loved this game.

With the launch on the 29th of july here they finally added and changed things that always kept me from enjoying this game hardcore. A smooth leveling experience now, less focus on PVP and PVE missions, stories and instances and a much more ease of access crafting system.

the world is gorgeous the hardsuits are fun and each has a different playstyle and I would honestly call this the PVE answer to APB being pvp.

if you hate player vs player but love shooter mmos and enjoy exploring..this game might be for you.


the cash store is filled with quick ways to level(nothing pay to win) ease access hardsuits(you can earn them in game leveling) and tons of fun cosmetics.

the only real cons I can think of, I get motion sick on my bike xD and sometimes the combat feels a little jerky. But all in all a fantastic solid game with of course the odd bug and glitch but well worth it.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Firefall was one of the most saddening trainwrecks of a game that could have been absolutely beautiful. I played since closed beta, was a founder, and spent a ridiculous amount of time on this game pre-steam. Every time I go to check back in on it and possibly come back, I hear about yet another wipe. Yet another core system change. I  played thorugh probably 3 tree wipes, weapon system redesigns, etc. They kept changing their mind on things right after people got fully used to the new system. It's absoutely unreal and if you want a good stable game that you can eventually learn everything in and not have to worry, this isn't it. Odds are they will rework an entire system every few months like it seems they've continued to do. And then you have to re-learn and re-grind.

This game was so golden when it first released and in beta. I don't know why red had to kill it.

reviewText: Really cool and fun game. And while it might seem like it's pay 2 win at first glance it's actually not since you have currency exchange to buy all the premium currencies with basic one (well you upgrade crystalyte to credits and credits to red beans) ofcourse there's a daily limit to how many you can convert but still. Alos majoroty of the premium" stuff can also be sold on exchange for credits.(I guess I could say it's pay to obtain stuff faster).\nAnyway overall the game feels like mix between Borderlands (graphics
date:
questing and open world wise) and warframe considering you have multiple battleframes and only one character. I haven't tried PvP aspect yet personally but people claim it's fun so I'll take that for granted atm.

As for battle frames at the moment start with 5 basic frames and there's 11 more advanced frames so there's 16 in total at the moment. Now to get advanced frames you have 3 options:
1(captain obvious): Buy them for red beans
recommended:
2 buy them for credits from exchange
3 level up any frame to lv40 to get 10 tech points with which you can buy the for.

Now while the game is extremely fun it doesn't come without flaws. For instance jobs get repetitive and boring as hell and since the objectives get placed randomly it sometimes places them on weird places like on top of the mountains. It also seems like the game requires a bit of skill to progress since ranged enemies hurt like hell and mobility is key to not getting shot so use your jetpack all the time and don't stand still.
Another flaw I noticed is lack of "extensive" tutorial so it might get confusing for new players there is tutorial for basics but it doesn't involve the crafting system which and how to obtain materials (besides thumping).
Also 1-use items are quite annoying especially the glider pads since I tend to use them every cooldown cuz they're fun. They are reusable(permanent) ones but they're a bit expensive.
Thumping to gather resources while fun at first it gets tedious when you have to wait for 5min to get that x amount of metals and dirt.

Now let's go back to the fun parts.
1. Quite emersive selection of frames which involves different playsyles also you can combine skills from basic with advanced frames of same type.
2. OMG jetpack. fun to use especially if you're like me and use it constantly to climb mountains and then...
3. ...use glider pads to glide around like a baws.
4. nice graphics really nicely done world and different settings from beaches
hoursPlayed: mountains
voteText:
forests and deserts.
5. Random events that happen across the map and some give quite a bit of experience (especially tornadoes)

Soo overall I'd give the game about 8/10 grade since it's not perfect there are some issues and it's not next-gen either but overall the fun I had in the game for past couple of days beats all the flaws. It's especialyl fun when you play it with friends and just mess around."

reviewText:
It sucked in beta two years ago, and it sucks now. Nothing has changed. Performance is a joke for a game that looks like a PS2 game, controls are decent, combat is fine if not basic, controls are good tbh, story is a throw away, environemts are littered with adverts for in game item that cost real money. Now back onto performance, for a game that looks this bad graphically it should run a million times better than it does with everything maxed out 1080p Ultra settings I get lowest of 38fps in starting town, and highest of 190fps... that is a massive jump. Even using vsync does not help as the game still has random loading sectons where you can tell its buffering the next area and the fps goes nuts. I have the lastest drivers and updates for my system and my system is no sloutch with an i7 4770K @ 4.5GHz and a 3GB HD7970 1150/1650 and 16GB 1866MHz RAM. I can max out Crysis 3, Metro LL, even ESO and still get smooth playable frame rates in those games that look ten times better than this game.

Overall, download it and try for your self, it is free afterall but I bet you will uninstall it after an hour.

PS/ I sunk 16 hours into the BETA 2 years ago and I sunk 1.5 hours into this release on steam.... ITS INDENTICAL!!!

I played the game in the beginning ( beta) upon the release the game went quiet real fast. The land you walk/fly/glide/drive around in felt really empty. in higher stages. reviewText:
Great game! Visually stunning, this  world is HUGE. You only need 1 toon and can choose from any class you like, dont like the class you chose? No prob just goto a battleframe machine and choose another, whatever lvl you hit previously is saved and you start off at lvl 1 again. There are main missions that activate at certain lvls but most times you can just do whatever you like. Missions from a job board for extra benefits or just roam around helping people.

One thing i like in this game that i've seen in no other is the reward system. If you happen upon a person or group doing a mission or event and help out, you still get part of the reward and loot even if not in a group with them.

Real money ingame is in red beans but there is ingame credits that you can get via selling stuff on the market or exchanging crystite for credits on the market exchange. Crystite you get from mission rewards or from killing mobs and even crafting things. Anything you can buy with real money ingame you can get with credits. This isnt pay to win, real money just makes things faster (i'm a patient person) This game is so addictive its hard to break away. It has a ton of ingame achievements, way more than in Skyrim or Borderlands 2. Explore the world.

Free to download and play, try Firefall today!

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for 2 years and 4 months and it came a long way. I can only pick a few games which developers have been so forth coming, talkative and able to listen to a community like ours (during beta). I could only name another few games that i've been involved in where we were so close to the developers, and they made it a point to roll with the community in terms of feedback and gave their interpretation to that feedback in a subsequent update.

So you know about firefall right ? You can simply visit the store page for more information, but from what I've seen I can make a few  good points of this game.

Progressing:
You have about 16 battleframes to choose from. You can choose only a few if you're picky about your game style (as a support or, healer, sniper or tank), or you can choose to level up many of these frames and join in on the massive world in battles with the game style which you think is right for the specific battle at hand.

Customizing,
You can customize how you look ingame, (in the 24th century you can even change your sex, allong with the rest of the usual suspects, body/hair color, battleframe color, some logo's etc....

Crafting,
It's completely OPTIONAL!. You'll be able to just play because firefall is foremost a shooter first!. You'll earn new rewards as you just shoot away and do quests/missions. But if you want to specialize in certain craftmanships you can do it and make your awesome weapon, to use for yourself or to sell on the market!

Market
Firefall has a market where - if you don't want to craft, or if you want to earn some money - you can rely on to get supplied.

Dynamic content:
You can literally wander in this vast world and do ares jobs/missions, then as you are doing your duties for the Accord, you stumble upon other dynamic adventures that you'll have to solve such as crashed objects that arrouse wildlife around it, coy transportation raiders, people being trapped, criminals on the run for the Accord and much much more.

Global events, invasions
And if that's not enough, there are organized massive events in this game which take place from time to time and invite everyone to contribute to the global war against te... umm I mean the chosen!.

In Firefall, you participate at your own level, sometimes in a squad, sometimes solo, sometimes in a hefty fight against a boss that will make your neck stiff. These titans will be for the hardest of the hardest (or so Nostromo says.. well at least I think he says that)

You can travel the world on foot inbetween missions, or benefit from gliders and vehicles to soar high above the sky when you go on your adventure. Everything is possible.

Now don't become chosen jawbones!

reviewText: It had promise once, even while they were changing the resources and progression a few dozen times, even while they promised the thumper grind would change, around the time they nerfed abilities into the ground. Then they obliterated and discarded an interesting progression system for a standard level-based slog, made the main and original area of the game an unexciting starter zone, ditched the amazing sieges and world content and started pushing more and more microtransactions and F2P gates, all while making vague and half-hearted attempts to write some lore into the game, forgetting any sort of progress or coherence.\n\nIt's a disappointment of the worst kind; one that was almost good until lack of coherent direction and an unwillingness to take the slightest risks turned a promising, vibrant, fast-paced shooter into a run-of-the-mill shrink-wrapped Game™.

reviewText:
I've put roughly 180 hours into Firefall so far. I say so far because I can see me putting in a whole lot more. Now I can see why people wouldn't like this game. Yes it has bugs (other than the ones you kill). Yes sometimes mission objectives don't load & you have to restart the mission again. Some times enemies just vanish while your shooting them. But having played a lot of this over the last 2 weeks I can say that there is a lot more to this game which will outway the glitches & bugs.

So how is this different to any other MMO? Well apart from being a FPS or 3rd person shooter not much really. It has the same go kill this for this reward quest system. It has instances. It has raids. You find better gear to increase your character to be better for end game content. You can farm missions for resources and currency. You grind to get certain items. So pretty much the same story as any MMO.

Well yes. But there are a few things that make this game stand out from the others. The dynamic world events are always ongoing. You will not be left standing around very often with nothing to do. From killing death teams to fighting for control of a thumper (machine used to extract resources from the ground). There is always something going on. I know other games such as Guild Wars 2 offer world events but not on the same scale as Firefall.

The fighting in this game feels great. Feels like a really good FPS or 3PS. It feels like it should. I personally play in First Person and really enjoy jumping around dodging snipers and plasma cannons trying to shoot me down as I fire thermal rounds burning everything in sight. Its a lot of fun.

Thats this games biggest asset. FUN. Yes it can be played seriously in a group in a raid situation. And yes if you roll in to a group instances under geared your probably going to be getting some abuse from the other players. But if you gear up properly you and your friends can have a lot of fun blasting away the enemy using plasma cannons, thermal cannons, poison shots, grenades, bombs and more. It can get really hetic.

I would recommend this game to people who enjoy MMO's. This is not a pick up and play FPS. There is crafting and researching and levelled gear which you would normally find. So if your a MMO player give this a go. Yes its rough around the edges but its always being updated, theres tons to do and in a group its a hell of a lot of fun. It's also free to play (and can be played for completely free. Only real money is used for vanity items & VIP status which gives you a xp, money and reputation boost.)

There was a really cool event with pushing melding front back for a limited amount of time, where is it now?

There was more content and action in beta then in 'finished' game.

For those of you that don't know, Firefall is an MMORPG/FPS with optional 3rd person view. (Nice to have both honestly.) In terms of look and feel its kinda like Halo and Crackdown had a baby then sent it to WoW School. You may read that last sentence and say but...I...how..." Just trust me on this. A lot of gameplay will feel familiar and natural. Much of the mechanics will seem very familiar as well if you have ever played an MMO like WoW.

reviewText:
I have spent a lot of time in the (long) Beta of Firefall before the official launch and have enjoyed the game always even though it has changed a great deal. The Red5 developers are good at listeing to feed back and fixing bugs - so please use the Firefall forums and in-game bug reporting to give your feedback and report bugs.

Even though Firefall is now officially (July 15 2014) no longer Beta it still will be always getting better and Red5 will always be looking for your input I am sure.

This is one of my favorite games. It has very low technical demands to run (my current system is from 2006 and still runs it fine), and the community of players is very supportive and helpful. Game play is great with lots of frenzied action and informal group play. You don't have to join an Army to have fun playing with others, and the dynamic randomly generated events give things to do for solo and group players both. There are things for you do to solo, and just as much if not a lot more to do with others.

It's free - so try it out!

reviewText: Do you like Global Agenda? Borderlands? FPS? TPS? This is the game for you. You can play either in First person or Third, and both play smoothly.  The gameplay is wonderfull, its not overly hard like Global Agenda, but you will share your fair part in death.  The graphics play smoothly on any settings, yet on worst settings the game still looks... good, suprisingly, the paid for currency does not, I repeat DOES NOT, run this game, if you want the paid for currency, you can trade the normal currency in game to other players for it, most of the marketplace it completely run by the players, it is honestly a great game. Plenty of gameplay, open world, shoot ♥♥♥♥, blow ♥♥♥♥ up, randomly occuring missions that only take about 2-mins to complete but still reward you hansomly for it, and the leveling system... its sexy as hell, you can choose one of 5 main specilizations, Dreadnaught, Assault, Recon, Robotics, and Biotech, once you reach level 40 with one of these, you unlock the next teir class within that specilization, with an average of 3-4 different classes within each specilization.  The crafting system is complex, but simple at the same time, simply melt down some scrap gear, research some new gear, craft some new gear, and vwolia, it takes some time but thats all really, the drops in the game are pretty well ballanced, the gear for any class works well, no one class is better than another, only sad thing is, there is not a Melee based class/specilization, im looking forward to the game getting one... Among all these things the game does have some problems... the gameplay feels quite repetitive after some time, leveling a fame aside from the first one you chose is no fun what so ever, the story seems quite linear so far, hostiles are boring and reused, limited areas to explore, ect ect, past all of this it does it quite a long road ahead of it, it could get quite better. honestly go play the game yourself, but all in all i quite like the game, i hope it does improve though...  6.5/10

reviewText: Firefall is pretty amazing.  I'm really surprised at just how well this game turned out at launch.  I would highly recommend this game to anyone, and I'm generally pretty wary of free-to-play games.  The gameplay is solid, and being able to choose between first and third-person perspectives is a wonderful addition.  Each of these perspectives functions equally well, as opposed to some other games that don't handle the transition well at all.  Shooting, questing, resource gathering, crafting, customization, it's all here.\n\nThe graphics aren't too taxing to play on older systems, and they look nice and stylized, though it's apparent they were not going for a realistic style.  The art direction is very unique, and the world never feels dead" or copy/pasted.  There are tons of nooks and crannies to explore
date: and even months later the starting zone is still interesting.  I've never experienced that in an MMO before.\n\nThe sound design is equally as well-thought-out as the gameplay
recommended: and I've found myself humming some of the tunes to myself on more than one occasion.  It's an interesting mix of instrumentation that I wouldn't expect to find in a game like this.  Whomever composed this soundtrack did a wonderful job.\n\nThere's a lot to enjoy here

reviewText:
If they gave us power armor with jump jets, but not cool aliens to shoot in the face, it would have been enough.

If they gave us cool aliens to shoot in the face, but not deep story with voice acting, it would have been enough.

If they gave us deep story with voice acting, but not a unique sci-fi future, it would have been enough.

If they gave us a unique sci-fi future, but not a variety of weapons and abilities, it would have been enough.

If they gave us a variety of weapons and abilities, but not a beautiful world to explore, it would have been enough.

If they gave us a beautiful world to explore, but not a PvP zone, it would have been enough.

If they gave us a PvP zone to meet new and interesting people... and kill them, but not vehicles, it would have been enough.

If they gave us vehicles to drive where we please, but not gliders to soar from the heights, it would have been enough.

If they gave us gliders to soar from the heights, but not made it free to play, it would have been enough.

If they made it free to play, but not put it on Steam, it would have been enough.

If they put it on Steam, then you could be playing it now instead of reading this.

How much more, then, are we to be grateful to Red 5 for all these good things they have indeed done for all of us!

reviewText:
Pros: The combat still has an intuitive vibe to it still -meaning- the gameplay predominatly plays like an fps before anything else, creating a Tribes feel to it. It also has much more exploration due to larger content increases.

Cons: The mechanics such as crafting are really simplified to the point where the only harvested minerals you recieve from crafting from lvl1-20 are basically raw earth, iron, tungston and crystite. There is a lot of traveling around which would disencourage lower leveled players; however there is a transit system.

This iteration of the game is really casual; however, it still makes unique differences to clasical MMORPGS mechanics such as combat and travel. It lacks in complexity, making it easier to learn, but leaves the player empty because progression is slow and learning stops at a certain level of play.

I would still recommend this game solely for it's combat. ie: jet boots mixed with gunplay. It makes the grind somewhat bearable at least to level 40 for one frame.

reviewText:
Firefall is a fairly fun game. It's free to play; microtransactions are present, but for the most part you can get items off the Cash Shop (Red Bean Store) with currency earned in game. It's a first person/third person shooter with jumpjets. The game world is interesting if you are into the sci-fi genre. I started playing when it game finally released a month or two ago, and I'm still enjoying myself. I haven't spent a penny on the game, yet I've unlocked almost all the advanced frames within that time frame. Also, the gunplay isn't too bad, only annoying thing is sometimes the enemy's movements are a bit off/unpredictable/laggy, but that could be due to my horrid wireless connection.

I'll end my gibbering with a pros vs cons list.

PROS:
+Interesting Sci-fi world with vast room to expand (both lore/story-wise and game content-wise)
+Third/First person shooter
+Jumpjets!
+Free to Play with not alot of Pay to Win content (A Bike/LGV is great for running around, but I believe you can get one early on now, instead of waiting to level a frame to 25)
+Cash shop items can be bought with in-game currency.
+5 base frames with different playstyles mixed in with a fair number of advanced frames to change it up.
+Customization of your character is free (recent patch gave everyone all the haircuts/facial hair options)

CONS:
-Not a huge amount of things to do once you've hit max level (level 40 right now)
-Glitches/bugs can sometimes be an issue (which is normal for an newly released game, sadly)
-Mostly a PvE (Player vs environment) game with a PvP (Player vs Player) mode and area sort of tacked on.
-Is a bit grindy ( at least your not paying for it, eh?)
-Some parts of the game aren't as well balanced as they could be.
-Crafting in the game is widely considered a bit of a joke and a waste of time (Recent patch has reduced the cost of some items as well as allowing for you to pick what subtype of item you want, but the reseach costs I believe have stayed the same. Less of a crapshoot, but still costly).
voteText: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This is a Borderlands type MMOFPS. It's basically a beautiful, open world play ground where you roam from job to job, while enroute being constantly side tracked with fun events that randomly spawn through the world. Every 2 or 3 levels the game moves you to a new location, keeping things fresh. Hang gliding through the sky never gets old. The core game is PvE based and highly encourages players to help each other as you pass by them. Everyone reaps the rewards as long as you pitch in. The crafting system is fun along with the mining system. Send a thumper crashing into the earth to mine resources. Refine those resources. Research abilities, weapons etc from research points you get from salvaging junk and old gear and then craft items based on all of those factors. The instance based missions are challenging if you do not get a fair amount of players on your team. The voice acting is great and the graphics are still nice to look at after almost 40 hours of gameplay.

Things that I do not care for. Job board missions take you all over the map. This is to entice you to purchase either VIP which gives you a special anytime glider pad to put down or purchase a motorcycle. Motorcycles are badass but cost a ridiculous amount of real world money. There is a way to exchange in game currency for Red Beans (real world $) but as usual this takes such a grind that you would have to dedicated" (a nice way to put it) to get anywhere doing it. I have VIP'd a for a few months but I also think that is a little pricey as well.

The cosmetics for your player are great. Battleframes to purchase with real money look great along with accessories. All the class in the game are available for free and all are fun to play. Whether your healing or throwing down turrets or just walking down Chosen with a huge gun. There is something for every play style.

This game took a beating in the reviews when it first dropped but has greatly improved since. It is free to try and definitely worth a shot."
voteText: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
YES I recommend this game! I've been playing it since way back in 2013 beta and even before that. There are some things that have changed for the better, some not. At first a character leveling system with zones with suggested level requirements seemed like a bad idea because while the game was back in beta everything was no level and free open roam. The game is one big grindfest from start to finish and everything starts to feel the same fast, but there are much more side things to do now to help lessen the grind and many more areas to explore. The combat is somewhat more janky than a AAA could have done with the game but after getting used to it and cutting them some slack because they are a indie dev, the game's combat can be pretty enjoyable. I personally just wished the game's combat mechanics would have evolved and feel more smooth but the combat is the same now as it was in early beta years ago. However overall it is pretty satisfying once you get into it. Pretty much the game's biggest problem is just being extremely grindy.

The game looks and sounds beautiful. The graphics are, generally speaking, not great in technical terms. But what makes the game look so outstanding are the color palette's used and the art direction, and the colors of the water and the sky. Everything does look very good art-wise and pretty clean. The game is bright when it needs to be bright, without being offensive, and in darkness everything being lit up at night looks fantastic. The sounds are great and the music sets the tone perfectly for whichever situation you are in. Definitely one of the best looking games you can find.

Flying on gliders across beautiful landscapes and riding a badass fast motorcycle across them never gets old. But continually grinding BK and job boards does. Thankfully you can mix it up and while doing a job board mission you can do side activities on the map while in the mission.

The game has shaped up nicely over the years. It stayed in beta so long I thought it would never be released. I have put a lot of hours into it and have just recently got back into it after over a year absence. Do I miss how it was back in beta, the no levels, go anywhere you want/thump anywhere you want world? Absolutely. But the game has not changed for the worse. There is a lot more in the game to do now and a lot more areas to explore. So overall, I like what I see right now and will be putting some more time into the game for at the very least a moderate while.

*** A quick word on optimization/coding. It isn't optimized and/or coded so great. I don't run it on ultra with my gtx 970 because in big events it gets hardcore slowdown. 'Very high' is where I run it, and switch to high or medium during massive event firefights. The game has its share of hiccups and stutters, but not bad stutters from video problems, just some hiccuping from latency and texture loading and even occasional rubber banding, but overall not enough to detract from your experience provided you have both good internet and a good gpu. ***

One of the best, or at least most fun, mmo's out there that is f2p. Tons of fun, especially to play with friends. Do not pass this up if you like mmo's, third person shooters, or top notch art direction. Just be prepared to invest a lot of time into it unless you bore easily from inevitable grinding.

8/10

reviewText:
This game has come such a long way in such a small amount of time- Red 5 has taken on adversity head on and triumphed. They have attempted many different things in their beta before setting in stone what they were finally going to do with Firefall, and the result of this approach has paid off.

This game is the most addictive game I've played in years. And I'm likely going to play it for years to come.

There's so much to do in the game- there's open world missions that just spawn in front of you, there is also a job board, there are instanced raids and quests, there are mini-encounters. There is open world PVP. Bikes to race with. Gliders. Did I mention jetpacks?

With 16 battleframes to choose from, and more on the way, and the ability to customize each to your liking, there are unlimited ways to play the game, catering to a vast array of playstyles. I could say so much more, but really- just try it out. You have nothing to lose. The game is free.

reviewText: It's a good game that has had a troubled development history, in part because of particular member of management who is no longer with the company. The game itself is fun and is evolving. There certainly are things that can be goals to work toward, but how you approach the game is up to you. You are not funneled down the same path as everyone else.

reviewText:
This game man is really great. Here's what my opinions are.

1) Don't complain if the games feels the same type of mission all over again, ALL GAMES are like that including REAL LIFE.

2) The borderlands game franchise feels right in this game, which is a plus.

3)Open world, lots of places to go through out all countries all areas. It's how you progress that lets you explore.

4)Slow lvl system so that no one can just burst through levels, they actually gotta craft, get better gear, team up to complete missions.

5) By judging at this game as a closed beta tester, I say there's lots of new contents/DLCs the devs can do.

6) Cool customizations, guns, rides and also the texture of the world itself.

7) my personal favourite, it makes you immerse into FireFall universe.

Here's the cons

1) Some gears can be purchase so those who spent on real $$ have the better chance of Solo-ing or PVP

2) The Quest board is a little bit slow on loading the next objective, a minor complain but still need to improve on that.

3) It wouldn't hurt if there's cinematics after certain levels you have gone up to. It makes the game more attractive, more fun, and you will feel like you're doing something like SWTOR. They have each cinematics after each mission completed, which is why the story line is darn good. I just hope FireFall will take that as a consideration.

DO I recommend this game? I say YES, this is BY far the second or THE BEST Shooter MMO besides Defiance of course.
You shoot monsters, bandits all sorts of Aliens that screwing you. It's a war here, just like Borderlands, Defiance ect. Also it takes place in the future on earth and you need to defend it.

reviewText:
Fun yet boring...

The game is setup pretty well at first glance. Good environment, good background story, nice praphics and a very good soundtrack. And when you start playing for your first couple of hours the game feels very good as well and seems to be a lto ot fun. That is until you've played a while, have hit level 15 or so and see the repeting of missions starting.

Firefall uses 'Job Board's to give you missions. Sadly the number of different missions is pretty limited. This results in missions starting to repeat themself, though not literally, but you will see the same kind of objective on new places and an other sugarcoat around it.

Skills and progression is an issue as well. You only have 4 skills and at level 8 you alreayd have them all. At that point you'll only be working on upgrading the skills itself. Either through research & crafting or by grinding vouchers to buy them from NPCs. Research & crafting really takes forever, while vouchers drop you back in the repeatative mission grind.

On a positive note, the cash shop is not Pay2Win. There are no game breaking items in there, and you can obtain the cash shop currency (Red Beans) from in-game grinding. With that, cash shop items are tradeble, and you can find almost everything from it on the auction house.

reviewText:
Well guess its about time for me to finally write a review. Just going to start off by saying I've been around with Firefall for ages now, all the way back since closed alpha, hell my character is still the same original one. Over the years I have seen A LOT of core game changes, like so many I don't even remember all of them. A few changes were for the better, such as when progression was sideways, you aren't trying to gain levels but work on aspects about your frames by gathering resources to use. At least to memory this was my favorite of the systems, it was good.

So right now we're sitting at version 1.7 if I'm not wrong, and yet again more changes to the core systems. Battleframe cores, which wasn't something I liked all that much to begin with, are now gone and replaced with generic armor pieces.  Old modules were replaced with new ones, honestly can't tell you why this was changed. Best guess is to have one kind of module rather than weapons and ability varients, still all in all I don't know why this even happened.

Entire weapon classes have been changed, and this one seriously pisses me off. Rhinos are one of the dreadnaught arctype frames that used to carry a laser heavy machine gun, it was pretty awesome, and it worked basically how it sounds, a machine gun that shoots lasers. It also had an alternate fire that was a fairly neat and useful single continuous beam. Well the new Photon Lance has all the features of the old laser HMG, but without the machine gun part. To put it bluntly, what used to be an alt fire is now a completely standalone weapon. Oh it also has a fantastic range of 20 meters which basically puts the least defensive of the slow dreadnaught frames at a very close range to the enemy. Makes complete sense obviously.

Look, Firefall is my baby. It is a game that I've been coming back to time and time again over the ages, no other MMO has ever received the same treatment from me. I care about this game a lot, and I seriously want it to succeed, believe me. Just... someone out there has decided to shoot themselves in the foot in a really bad way, in the past Firefall has been amazing and fun as hell. That Firefall isn't what we have anymore, its a shame honestly. Well, with the game's constant history of changes maybe we'll see something good again in the future, but I don't think so.

reviewText:
Hi-

Just wanted to throw in my two cents.  If you like Borderlands or other FPSs, this is well worth a try.  It's truly free-to-play; you can play this indefinitely without paying a cent- you will not reach a point that you have to cough up money for.  Leveling will take you a bit longer without buying VIP membership (which boosts XP and some other things), but it's not all that big of a deal.  I have friends that have played for over 100 hours without buying anything.  Plus, you can buy the vast majority of items with in-game money if you want to put the time in.

The big draw for this is the fun of leveling different classes, and developing gear.  There is more end-game stuff to do than in Borderlands, for instance.  Don't get me wrong... the BL franchise is my favorite by far, but you reach a point where you have everything and have done everything.  I found that in FF, there is always something to do, if you adjust yourself to wanting to do it.  If you can find a few buddies or join a squad/ army, the possibilities increase.  The MMO feature allows you to meet new players, if you want to, and go from there.

I've read the negative reviews, and most of them seem to come from disappointed beta players.  I came to the game just after official release, so I can't really speak to what is was like and what may or may not have changed.  There is a grinding aspect to the leveling, but more so because there are 16 frames to level up, if you want.  However, it's no more grindy than BL, with the increasing level caps and having to repeat Vault Hunter modes several times.

So, I'd strongly recommend giving this a try.  I continue to be surprised that more people haven't tried it, but I suspect it's because of suspicion about the MMO feature.  I felt the same way, but I gave it a try.  What game have you played that you can play for a year or more and still find fun things to do in it?

reviewText:
A lot of people complain about this game, and I will explain why after pointing out all of the AMAZING things in Firefall.

Here's a bit of my background with the game: I have been playing on/off for the past 4ish years, ever since the beta in 2012. I have several thousand hours put into this game, though the amount shown on Steam is certainly lessbecause Firefall only went onto Steam somewhat recently. I have played, levelled, and mastered nearly every battleframe (battleframes are Firefall's version of classes) and have been endgame in every major expansion this game had since the release.

Firefall is an open world MMORPG that is played as either a third person or first person shooter. It is a scifi style game in the future, so your guns and equipment are futuristic and you get a jetpack that lets you fly/hover in the vast open world. Combat is extremely fluid and the class (battleframe) options let people of all play styles enjoy the game in their own way. Do you like to jump around while shooting, being extremely agile and hard to hit? Pick an assault battleframe. Do you prefer sitting in the back while sniping? Recon battleframes are right for you. There are many other options to choose from if you have different play styles, and you have access to every frame on one character (though you have to unlock the ones you didn't choose to start with).

The story is original, the graphics are appealing, the audio effects are nice, and the character customization options are awesome. Unlike most MMORPG's, you can change your character appearance and sex for free, so your customization options are completely unrestricted. There are many different ways to build your character for combat, with tons of different upgrades to weapons, a perk system, multiple weapons to choose for each battleframe, plenty of secondary weapons, and a wide variety of abilities. The game is completly free to play and you never get forced to pay real money. Firefall is not even close to pay to win. Spending real money gets you: cosmetics, experience boosts, toys, and currency conversion (which you can easily get for free with ingame currency as well).

The community is AMAZING. If someone asked me which game I think has the best community, I would immediately answer Firefall. Even GM's come and play with us, creating massive events that give amazing rewards just for fun. To me and many others, this community is a family, and every new player is welcome.

Firefall sounds pretty great, right? Well, a lot of people are leaving/complaining about the game because of some big changes that happened in January 2016. The game used to have a lot more content, more open world zones, more raids, a better story, and fewer bugs. After the big update in January, the game essentially became a worse version of itself. There are a lot of bugged missions that may make levelling a bit more annoying because players will have to find working jobs/missions. If you can ignore the bugs, Firefall is actually a great game still. Sure, it's not what it used to be, but it isn't bad.

The game is free, so it's always worth a shot. Playing with friends would definitely make the game a lot more fun, so try and talk to others in the zone chat. Firefall players are generally very friendly and helpful. Firefall is one of those games that can keep you hooked for ages, so if you want something fresh and exciting to keep you going for the next few weeks, months, or even years... you've come to the right place.

Thats if the game wasent plagued with so many bloody bugs.  Myself friends and others ive seen in game have had multiple problems with broken quests quest objectives taking 5 or more mins to upload countless times ive or others have had to reload the game to move on to the next quest objective.  Problems with puting items up on the auction house etc I could go on for a long long long time about the bugs.  Basicaly easyest thing to say is this has to be the bugiest mmo ive ever played.  Now like I said at the start it is a lot of fun when you arent plagued by the bugs so if the devs ever wake up and start fixing alot of these problems it can and will be one if not the best f2p mmos out there.

reviewText: Horrendously underrated. FireFall is an addictive MMOFPS with a mixure of elements from Borderlands, Sanctum 2, an a little bit of Section 8, and while it doesn't deliver on the best aspect of each one, the way it meshes together is really great, and adds for a fun experience. The way people get together whenever a mission pops up, while not original (I heard Guild Wars 2 has a similar mechanic), is a blast, which raises it above other F2P MMOs, and the gun combat is engaging and satisfying. Progression feels genuine, and more often than not, FireFall does NOT feel like a free to play game, though there are times when it does lose that illusion, such as a store window popping up for red beans" and cosmetic items."

reviewText:
For a free-to-play shooter, Firefall isn't honestly that bad. So far I've been impressed and have been more into playing this than Advanced Warfare (I got both at the same time). The game is open world and full of things to do, giving the player hours of enjoyment.

One thing that I love about the game is aesthetics, which most games (especially in the triple A industry) don't have. The colors green and blue are quite common. It's nice for some producers to understand that we don't all want maps or overworlds that are obliterated. A large undevastated world awaits people. I wouldn't say it'll make your jaw drop, but you'll notice some other colors in the world.

The combat is a little wobbly with the game lagging or freezing for a brief moment. However, as long as your internet is decent and your computer can run the game semi-well then you shouldn't have an issue. Now, I mentioned AW for one reason. Both of these games involve vertical gameplay somewhat. AW you have the extra jump, and in this game you have a jumpjet (I call them jetpacks). It makes it fun when you need to avoid an enemy, so you jump around him like a queer fairy lighting him or them up. The combat is interesting, but quickly turns into a grind, as most mission involve you going to a location to kill something or escort, or rescue. But all of them involve you killing something.

As for the pay system, it's overpriced. After a while I decided to look into some outfits. I picked out the Bandit eye goggles and the straw hat. 240 Red Bean total, or to put it in easy to understand term, $25. No, not going to happen. You can earn virtually everything in-game by grinding it, but it'll take some time.

Overall it's a good game. 7/10

reviewText:
Played this game during Alpha, Beta, I'm a proud Founder of it and still playing on release.  This game is not for everyone, if you played and loved such game like - Global Agenda... this game is for you.

Pros:
- Huge world to explore
- Sandbox game which have lots to do
- Random Jobs, Job board, Instance missions, Raid of 20 peoples and Open world PVP
- Solo or Group Thumping anywere you want in allowed area.
- Easy Crafting system, research and Refining your goods for mats and money
- Marketplace to sell your mats/Gear
- Very Fast paste gameplay, very addicting
- Free to Play!!

Cons:
- Vertical Progression, you need to level each frame up from lev 1-40
- When higher level, you will have to be in higher level areas... you can still help a freind as you will be dropped to a lower level in those area, but you gain near 0 exp per kill but still get some for missions.
- lots of grinding and repeatition of the same missions to reach Lev 40 on a frame

This game took a long time to get release, now it's only a matter of time and patience to see if the dev will continue giving us new content.

Thanks,
-Fkid-

reviewText:
Played this game alot during it's closed and open beta, and I've gotta say they've changed alot of stuff since then. Alot of the changes are pretty nice too.  The beta was a glitchy, buggy, repetitve(thou still could/can be), and kinda boring due to not having any content in the game to be involved with).  Since my few hours or so playing on the steam release I do gotta say....thank god no more half pants battle thongs on my bastion battleframe chick! lol (you beta guys know what i'm talking about). Anyway, here's my pro's and con's so far for new players interested in Firefall...

PROS:
-Beautiful graphics and not too tolling on mid-grade computers
-Action based combat system (no point and click)
-Rewarding Dynamic Events
-Simple crafting system (All depends on the person, some people like more complex crafting, I just find this one easy to learn and use.) (CRAFTABLE MOTORCYCLE AT LEVEL 25, AFTER DOING BOARD MISSION IN DREDGE CALLED In the Wheelhouse" *hint hint*)
-Guild Wars 2 style market system (trade in-game currency for cash-shop currency system)
-Storyline/Personal mission progression added to the game since beta ( looks like they might develop more story later on)
-Voice Acting for every mission and dynamic events (note: some of it is a bit amateur

reviewText:
This game could have been a open world sandbox skill based shooter with Massive PVE battles, skillfull PVP, and amazing story. Then 0.5 happen an the skill aspect began to fate away, and then hackers began over running the PVP. Then they added 15 frames removing the ability to customize your frames, and adding a grindy unenojable progession system. Then the game just turned into a stupid AOE spamming party with 2 seconds CD on abilities that would last 6-10 seconds. Lasty we have this a game with feature that are all poorly designed, very grindy, boring instances, unbalanced PVP that full of hackers, and with zero sandbox elements because of the new leveling system forcing players to stay in area that fit there level an following the dull mission board story line.

My best time playing this game was when they first added the chosen war system which made chosen come out of the melding, and take over watchtowers an towns. I would be heading to a town after gather materials thumbing an as i was heading back i would see a massive chosen platton just walk out of the melding, and starting capturing watchtower. Now chosen invasion are scripted events that happen ever so an so hours an weather you win them or not they don't affect anything.

An the gameplay so boring, and easy now i can solo a Squad 3 thumber with max level enemies. When they first added thumber soloing a personal thumber was brutal most people could barely fill it to 50%, Now enemies would be lucky if the health of a squad 3 thumber that being defend by one player falls under 75%.

Overall if you really want to enjoy this game beg the developers to reset the game to 0.4 or 0.5 (if you can stand the stupid poorly designed Tech tree progession) I personal liked 0.5 the most the tech tree was stupid, but the gameplay was great.

reviewText:
To start these off I played since the 2nd wave of beta, I am a VET of this game. It does and was always suppose to play like a MMO Borderlands. But reading some of the other comments some people do not feel the same way, so Im giving my views on the key issues people are talking about below. I hope you all atleast try the game and judge it yourself not what I or some one else says.

Well I played more then some of these most helpful reviews. I will be honest and will be fair I played sicne the 2nd beta wave. Since then I played 5 differnt games called firefall all were great some were better but this lastest one isnt bad. I like the levels give the game some direction (Some people may not like direction but it helps the most of us out imo). I love the new crafting system anyone seen the old one would of died trying to figure it out, sure some of the things have long research or build times just like ESO so log on put some thing on the cooker go to work come back bam its done! Yo umay want to plan ahead with the crafting system which some may see as a draw back but you dont have to afk  smelting like other mmos such as WoW. The class system, I have most of the classes but I do prefer the odler way of getting classes, but now you max a character then get a new one or farm one out with credits (In game currency) which isnt easy but isnt hard either after you do it amny time it may get old but take it slow enjoy the game dont rush it.

You get a free Bike if you do the right quest I had seen compalints about it but if there giving them away (Mid/late game) dont complain about them selling to those who want" it early game since they have a decent taxi systemj early game making bike not a need but a want. When you "need" a bike is when you get the quest for it. I enjoy the game so I told them to shut up and take my money but every one is differnt its worth a try.

Hope you enjoyed mt review and I hope to see you al lin the world too!"

reviewText:
Been playing this game since closed beta, and like all closed beta things change. The game play is very addictive, and if you got money to drop, id say buy an advance frame (about 10dollars) once you figure out what basic frame you like. And go from there.

This is a true FREE2PLAY game. You do not need to spend any money if you do not want to. But it helps the game thrive, if you do. Everything in the game can be bought off the market, including the RedBeans, (Real Money Currency). The leveling system is like most MMO minus you only have one character, and use battleframes which hold the levels on each frame.

The crafting system is coming along, i would assume it will still being tweak after the 29th, but once you figure out salvaging, and research points, you will be crafting in no time.

Firefall feels like a true living world, and a game. If you tried it during beta, i'd recommend you give it another shot.

reviewText:
Firefall. A name that means bugger all, yet is still easily insulted. Firefall is an FPSMMORPG and maybe some other letters of the alphabet with lyrics within songs that suspiciously remind of you of ♥♥♥♥. What kind? ♥♥♥♥ed if I knew, the blue kind that comes out of Aranhas. The crab-like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s within this game. You could even add RTS genre if you were commanding the monsters against the worthless human scum-- Which sounds like a much better game.

Anyway, Firefall is of a genre that even when abbreviated is longer than its actual full name. But at least games no longer have fifty seven digits after them, or enough colons to make a hard drive dry heave into the jet-blasters.

Oh, right, Firefall. The story starts after everything interesting happened, where the terrans, no not those ones, discover a space rock, made a ship from it because they suddenly know what space rock does, And then smashed it into the planet for plot! Well, that's my guess at least. They don't really explain why the ship crashes into the earth. Either way you were hired to use gun on bandit. Possibly smash it in the face- which is actually a more viable strategy than the guns that might as well fire BB'S. Unless you're the assault where the BB's shatter. Though, there aren't really that many bandits, it's mostly the wildlife because that's suddenly more dangerous than human with gun.

Actually, everyone whinges about these space f*cks that invade earth or whatever, but you never see them until about 10 hours in, or perhaps the story quests that you only have within the first area. But who cares about the story? Well, Me. The sole patrionist of Single player. Though the story is fun, I guess. But again, it's only in the first area, so there's nothing to interest you after the first area.

Too many negatives! I need to put my smiley mask on and dance around this pile of ♥♥♥♥ pretending to look I know what I'm doing, I mean until I find a good spot, like looking for carrot within vomi- I can't use that analogy because that's not hard to fin- OH I FOUND ONE! The class system is probably the best part of the game. There are five classes, 11 more that you can unlock either by dinging to level 40 with one class or using micro <Dry heave> micro transactions.

But wait!" I hear you say. "I thought you were going to talk about the good parts?" Oh

reviewText: To the surprise of everyone who has ever previously heard about this game, what's left of Red 5 studios actually managed to turn this trainwreck around and make it into a good and complete game less then 8 months after the schitzophrenic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a CEO, Mark Kern, who was almost singlehandedly personally responsible for the game not making any development progress in 3 years of beta, was fired.\n\nFirefall now has coherent and consistant design, along with a truly massive increase in content. It's like a mashup of Borderlands and Planetside. Definitely worth playing, it's free after all.

reviewText:
And the third and probably last big change to Firefall has came. And together with it, the last patch too probably.

I'm a Firefall Player since 2011 I guess. This game changed a lot. And for me, change isn't a bad thing at all. I liked some of the changes they made since the game had part of Copacabana and mobs dropped Tires as loot.
But this final game. Isn't for me anymore. And I've waited to this 1.7 patch to remake my review of the game.

The state of the game:
+Firefall have amazing combat/movement mechanics thanks to the core of the game being a Shooter.
+New user experience is good.
~PVP is feels good with some Battleframes.
~Mob AI is good when it wants to...
-The Story resembles a Power Ranger movie... yeah, it's that bad now. (sorry team DX)
-Questing feels familiar and not very satisfying. Fetch and all.
-Raids are filled with bulletsponges, the Boss Raids are also the same.
-Crafting is gone. (their first crafting system was amazing though.)
-Big events happen hourly in each map, but its there at least.

Should you play it?
Yes. It's free and as i said, new user experience is quite good. Exploring is cool and even better with friends to goof arround.
Should you keep playing it?
Nah, Red5 isn't going anywhere with this game. It will probably shut down pretty soon.

I still love this game with all my heart. Made a lot of friends in it and joined multiple Armies/Guilds" in the game. But i'll don't want to be here to see how it ends.

Thanks to BRASIL

reviewText:
This is pretty awful.
-Had to restart twice in 3.7 hours of play to fix mission bugs (One main mission, one job board)
-No direction of where to go. Level 1-5 area is shown, but then you have to randomly explore to find any other appropriate level areas.
-Large open area with fixed point, one-way travel systems. A lot of running through empty scenery.
-The gameplay seems consist of grinding until you get called for a story mission (which are actually interesting) then repeating.

reviewText:
Borderlands + diablo +TF2 + defiance = Firefall a unique Dynamic FPS/TPS-MMORPG/ i have played this game since the launch of open beta a few months ago and already saw its potential because of its unique setting and gameplay

The Community is supportive, its Free to play model is good since you can get like 95% of the content without paying anything.
The Economy in firefall has a lot of potential in it however since the marketing system got renewed after the 1.0 patch the market is still somewhat empty.

You can play this game in different ways whether you like to solo like me, or want to group up with your friends

reviewText:
I can't get over how clean this game is. Everything seems incredibly accessible, tightly packed and gorgeous. A few UI hiccups and the normal MMO bugs like odd mob spawning and lag seem to be worked around so it's not too bad.

I played a bit of closed beta so I'm glad to see this game finally released, I'll update my review after I get a few more levels and hours!

*Edit* 17 hours in and I'm addicted. I've been craving an MMO and FF far exceeded my expectations. I wish it was a bit more FPS than MMO but I can't complain. For a f2p, this game is tight. Better than most current MMO's.

*57 Hours Edit* Well I'm almost level cap and I'm excited to play a new class tomorrow for the actual launch. I'm thinking engineer but I want to hit 40 to get a pilot token and unlock Dragonfly.

I'm upset there's hardly any low level pvp, and I'll give a new edit after I hit cap and kill other people. I'm excited, but almost 60 hours in and I'm almost level cap with the 25% bonus experience, I'm very sure that there's not enough choices when it comes to grinding to get to cap level without VIP status. So while I want to say it'd be an extra 20 hours of grinding, it's even worse than that, because there's hardly enough missions after level 20 to get to the next level appropriate zone even with the Exp Boost. You'll probably end up running around, looking for ARES missions, crashed lgvs/thumpers and tornados.

Unless you just want to Thump all day with people. It's a damn good thing that's actually fun to do.

reviewText:
So far the game seems good fun, definitely worth a spin. It is a bit grindie. Nevertheless it's a shooter/mmo and you do get some satisfaction on shooting at monsters and bandits/aliens.
The questing stories while not the most original are still interesting and some will keep you pushing the game till high hours.
The critics are way too harsh especially considering the lack of quality on mmo's you have out there.
Truly free to play, no pay to win walls. Uses the same micro transaction system as Neverwinter Night.
There is a lack of players on early zones and the learning curve is steep when it comes to all the functionalities.

reviewText:
I like this game.  I don't feel like I HAVE TO play everyday to level up or make progress.  Just a little bit of time every once and a while when I have free time and am in the mood.

The game does have a lot of grind, and for most people that is a bad thing. However in my case, I sorta enjoy it.  I can just zone out and gain a few levels or earn some loot.

The pay model is nice.  You don't feel like you have to buy anything,  and that makes me want to buy stuff.  Anything you can buy in the store with cash, you can buy with in-game cash.  And in fact the boosts you can buy don't help all that much.  No mater how much you spend with real cash in the game, you will still have to actually play it just like everyone else.
