reviewText: Firefall is the MMO worth playing. It is free to play. You do not have to pay to win, but I would advise a player to at least  buy a glider and bike for traveling purposes. While you can get both without having to pay, it is worth the early investment for time.  I use the glider probably as much or more than the bike. The advanced frames (classes)are unlocked by maxing your level on the regular ones, or you can buy a new frame with the in-game currency. Most real money expenses come from cosmetics an short xp buffs. You don't need them to do well. The classes are all useful in one way or another. The Thumping" in the game is very enjoyable. Thumping is a way of mining
date: which is basically a "Protect this drill and kill everything that tries to eat it" game. There are invasions where the enemy Chosen will try to take over a city. There are real consequences if you let them do that (no access to quests/vendors in the area until it is retaken).\nThe storyline is also worth looking into; it will enrich the traveling and questing experience."

reviewText:
Not interested in a full review? Well here you go: This game is awesome, one of the best developers (if not the best). Can't see any pay-to-win either. Is pretty grindy, but hey, it's an MMO. Just try it.

I've been in beta for nearly 2 years. This game was in beta for an eternity, because Red 5 actually wanted to release a good game, not like many others today, releasing half-finished/broken games.
Nearly every game system/mechanic has been overhauled a dozen times, which, in my oppinion, shows, that they really want to find the best systems for this game.
The developers really listen to the community and are overall just awesome.
The game itself has awesome graphics, has a customizable UI and allows UI addons.
The story itself seems solid so far, but further episodes are not out yet. Most of the missions are replayable instances which are actually really fun. They also feature hardcore modes with all enemies at the maximum level.
The level cap is set at 40, though there are 16 frames (which are kind of like classes) that all have to be levelled individually. To earn experience you either do the mission instances, ARES Jobs/mission which are comparable to repeatable quests in many MMORPGs, do open world events or thump. I'd recommend getting some friends in, since higher quality thumpers (for better resources) and high level ARES Jobs are pretty hard.
What is thumping? It's basically mining. You call down a thumper which attracts enemies and has to be defended by you. Once it's full you recall it and get resources, which are used for crafting.
Crafting is one of the major aspects in this game. It's one of the ways to acquire better gear. You can also rely on drops, but it will probably take quite some time to find, what you're looking for.
The areas are vastly different, you will encounter pretty much everything from frozen to desert, with according enemies.
If you're ever bored, just go around and explore the world.
The nice thing is: You can go nearly everywhere on the map, no matter the level. You will probably be dying a lot in the high level areas, but it's not all about levels... if you are good at the game, you can also handle high level enemies. It's skill-dependent up to a certain degree.
The movement is also very unique in Firefall. You can walk and run, of course, but there are also Light and Medium Ground Vehicles to transport you faster. You have jumpjets, which are like jetpacks. You have enough energy to go about 3 seconds into the air, but it quickly recharges. This system allows for advanced movement. Another way to move around the world are gliders"

reviewText:
Firefall is one of my favorite MMOs.  If you like the feel of an open world environment (like most MMOs) and like third or first person shooters I recommend you give Firefall a try.

My fav features:
Movement.  Just getting around in the game is very fun.  Motorcycles, gliders, jump pads and personal jetpacks!
Dynamic quest system.  Repeating a quest does NOT mean you will go to the same location(s).
Open world content.  Imagine you are fighting some aliens for a quest and more (aliens, bandits, critters, etc) show up unexpectedly, due to random public content/events.  Time to react or die.  You have to think on your feet and be aware of your surroundings.
Crafted gear is useful!  A large percentage of the gear I use was crafted by my character.
One character, multiple battleframes (classes).  This means that your inventory and crafting is tied to your character, NOT your class.  So your battleframes level independently, but that cool level 20 submachine gun of doom you crafted for your main battleframe is usable by the battleframe you have reserved for playing with your group of friends (once you get that battleframe to lvl 20)
Free to play which means it should be easy to get your friends to try it.
You can buy things with actual money, but it's just cosmetic, quality of life, and fun items.  NO Pay to Win.
It's very common to be knocked down and have a complete stranger come by to revive you.
Playing with a group is fun.
What I don't like:
Software bugs.  Not a ton, but they are there.  Note:  vendor support is responsive.
Lot's of good changes coming in an update soon (maybe in January).  Check out this video for a summary (and some laughs):  video link

reviewText:
I've been playing Firefall since early closed beta. Its a game I keep coming back to even after other games have distracted me and then lost my interest. Firefall is uniquely brilliant, and some of the most fun I've had in a shooter.

The game is free. Totally free! It supports itself through sales of cosmetics in various forms and convenience, almost all of which can also be acquired with in-game currency on the marketplace. There is no Pay2Win here at all!

It's a beautiful world to explore and you will love the sheer amount of mobility you have. There are dropships, ground vehicles, gliders and jetboots/packs to cover all of your terrain traversal needs!

I cannot recommend this game highly enough!

reviewText:
This is a fantastic MMO. I love it. Rather than telling you about abstract qualities however, I'll just give an example of play. So this is what happened to me. I began in a richly detailed and populated city wearing a BattleFrame. I moved over to a terminal and got a mission from the local post-apocalyptic authority to help find a lost girl. I moved over to a glider-pad, was launched into the air and with a sonic-boom was projected forward with wings extended. I glided (under my own direction) down to a ridgeline before arriving at a bug-infested canyon. I proceeded to blast and grenade my way to gory victory by engaging in both horizontal and vertical combat before my ‘operator’ told me to start looking inside the bugs for the girl’s genetic material. Awesome.
With no genetic material found (she had not been eaten), I was directed over the hill in search of her SIN ID. That was went I came across another player managing a Thumper (basically a piece of mining equipment). She was holding off scores of bandits trying to steal her stuff. Back to back we fought, dropping goons all around us while exchanging instructions and words of encouragement. Achievement and experience were flashing before us as we looted the looters. Nothing was stolen or claimed and everything was fair. Finally, with a cinematic boost, the Thumper launched into the air and I was rewarded. She thanked me before I continued my mission.
I found the lost girl, finally, who had simply run away from home. As the mission was random (or at least I think it was) she happened to be in the middle of a nest. The ground erupted around us and the fighting began, as I struggled to save her. Turns out a convoy was being attacked nearby too so the result was a three-way firefight that got even more complicated when a team of three other players turned up. The gun-play was amazing and everyone had a great time fighting off the staggering number of critters that were involved. That was when I returned to base and began crafting. Let’s just say that the fun continued long after this.
The graphics are amazing, the quests are dynamic, the gameplay is solid and the community is supportive. Seriously, buy this game now.

reviewText:
There is quite some fun to be found in Firefall if you like to play an FPS and don't mind a little MMO and RPG with it. At its current state it has a couple of flaws so your milage on how much you enjoy it might vary.

Pros:
A quite large world to explore and a couple instances to tackle (with an optional hardcore mode for increased challenge)
Fast paced movement (jetpacks!) and skill based shooting (you actually have to aim, no tab targeting)
True free to play" - You can level to the maximum and play all the content without paying a cent.
No "pay to win" - You only pay to speed up progress (xp boost)
date: get conveniance items (e.g. permanent rechargable gliders) and cosmetics. None of this is necessary to level your character. Vehicles and many cosmetics can also be obtained on the market using ingame currency.\nPlenty of jobs (think quests) to do with dynamic missions and encounters thrown in. There is always something to do even if you're not looking for anything.\nIn case you hate finding a random group and ending up with undesirable people
recommended: you can solo almost everything (except for a few story based missions).\nPlayers can only exchange goods but no currency
hoursPlayed:
so hopefully gold sellers might find this game less attractive.
Plenty of add ons that make your life easier (check the add on forum on the Firefall site)
Cons:
Sluggish user interface and convoluted dialogs. Basically everything that is not related to moving and shooting seems to have been done by interns that just started there first lessons on user interface design and had a knack for eventually consistent databases. Oddly enough this is an area where the game has been redesigned a couple of times but never really improved.
Currently there is only Open World PvP
voteText: which is rather pointless as both casuals with green gear and hardcores with epic gear battle on the same instance. There used to be a skill based arena PvP with standardized gear but it was disabled quite a while ago and no schedule has been announced on when it will return. Either way
helpfulPercent: PvP is more about spaming your abilities than actually aiming and hitting or slowly building up proper team tactics.\nNo reasonable way to try an advanced battleframe before buying it. Sometimes there are weekends where you can try a single advanced frame for free. And there is a short period for new accounts where they can try out all frames (which sadly is at a time where you are already overwhelmed by figuring out the basic mechanics of the game).\nThe current endgame (at level 40) is mostly pointless grind
votesHelpful: there isn't anything particullarly useful to do.\nThings you should be aware of:\nPlaying through the various areas is linear
votesTotal: content is gated by level. You can replay lower content though (e.g. to help your newbie friend)
votesFunny: your battleframe automatically downgrades to a (somewhat) appropriate level.\nDistances between jobs can be quite large
commentsCount: which is annoying if you have no vehicle or recharable glider yet. You get a free LGV (think motorbike) when you reach level 25 with your first frame though. Be prepared to invest a little money to buy a vehicle early on.\nFrom the beginning you can use 5 different battleframes (think classes) which offer a lot of different play styles. Once you level a frame to 40
column16: you can unlock one of 11 advanced frames. As a rough estimate
column17: it takes about one hour to reach a new level.  Be prepared to invest a little money to buy your favourite battleframe early on.\nThere is no instance finder that automatically assigns you to a group
column18: so you have to go and find other people using the /zone chat. (There is a rather limited /lfg command
column19: but hardly anyone uses it
column20: thus it's pointless in practice.)\nThe crafting and researching mechanic require a lot of grind to use them effectively. I tend to ignore this and get by using random drops. This makes the game more interesting as you have to compensate the lack of decent gear with skills.\nThere are still quite a few bittervets around that complain about what the game could have been and how they have been betrayed by investing early on. Just ignore them. Yes
column21: it started out very ambitiously and ended up very traditionally. If you are looking for an innovative game
column22: better play something else."

reviewText:
I've been in Firefall for a while. Been interested in it since the infamous presentation at 2011 PAX. Not too long after that, I got in Closed Beta in one of first invitation waves.

The game really had potential. Unfortunately, throughout 2012 and 2013 there were some catastrophically bad decisions that were implemented in game. I've completely lost interest in it, so I took a break in 2013 and rarely would check up on it.

I've tried it again now that its officialy out, and I've gotta say: I'm amazed. They have completely turned the game around. It finally feels good, the design and mechanics make sense and are fun. It finally feels like it did over 2 years ago, and it feels good.

Firefall is definitely one of best F2P games out there at this moment.

reviewText:
You know, I haven't played this for too terribly long but here is a first impressions. It is similar to Desiny and Defiance combined. This game has a lot of potential. Thay being said, most of it is just that, potential. You can't go underwater which is disappointing, it feels like there isn't enough loot at all, even trash loot to scavenge or sell, and I don't even think you can just sell it but the salvaging system helps that. Also, you have to build or pay for a one use vehicle that disappears. Considering the distances you travel, it'd be better if it stayed with you.

It did a lot of things right though.
There is a decent crafting system from what I can tell, the salvaging system seems legit, being able to mine resources is awesome, decent gunplay and adding jetpacks (even if they are lacking) and having such a huge world. Now if only it was filled more with creatures that just roam around.

In conclusion, i'd try it, but i wouldn't blame anyone for not liking it

reviewText:
I started Firefall up for the first time and accidentally spent 6 hours on it.

At the lower levels levelling up isn't too much of a grind, especially if you end up wading into a few fights above your level. The game looks good, the environment is interesting and makes you want to explore a bit and so far the 'jobs' or objectives I've been doing have been holding my attention. You get a bit of backstory about the world you're in with most of the jobs, which is nice. You pick up knowledge about the world you're in as you go along.

Fighting the chosen (the bad guys) can feel a little overwhelming and frustrating as, if there aren't many players around you can get swamped pretty quickly, but the other players seem happy to get stuck in when they see another player in need, whether is't with a swarm of critters or a platoon of chosen.

Decent bit of fun for no cost. Also, you can dance.

reviewText:
Im not to far into the game yet, not even lvl 20. However this game seems pretty freak'n awsome...

First off im really glad to see an mmo move in a fresh new direction, i'm also glad to see the shooter genre being worked with in a new light. These two very popular game catagories havent seemed to chage much at all since mmos like Guild Wars 2 and the more recent Tera Rising which unfortunatly lacks a little depth. Even less evoulution has come from FPS (first person shooters) and 3PS (third person shooters). I have yet to play Destiny so i cannot comment on how it may have changed the shooter genre, but i have played a wonderfull 3ps mmo called Global agenda and let me tell you, was that game fun. Global agneda died out quite awhile ago it seems, even with rumor for a remake. But from what i have experienced so far, Firefall gives a very similar feeling to Global Agenda.

To be honest i was first sceptical of the MMOFPS Firefall. The screen shots depicted bulky looking character models and an impression of just another delevoper failing to reimagine the mmo genre -I was wrong.

It started on a night like most, I was dwindling on steam browsing for a new mmo to play, because for some reason i just couldent get back into playing WoW. I decided, hey what have i got to lose by atleast trying this new game? ahhh but first let me check youtube. And wow nothing but beople complaining aobut things like the inability to pick up multiple quests and finish them all at once and even more so about how long the game took to get out of beta. Sifting through all the hate i realized that DIFFERENT is exactly what i was looking fore. I have come to absolutly love that i can only do one quest or job" at a time in Firefall it makes the game feel more real and immersive for me. Each Job has new and unique fully voiced dialog with multiple characters and a suprisingly intricate story depth (per mission
date: or town set of missions). However there arent too many to do per town

reviewText:
I initially played Firefall because I was intrigued by its premise...but I was unfortunately unamused by the execution.  Standard gameplay largely consists of being tasked to go to a place, shoot at things, then go to other places to shoot at things until you return to the place you started.  Often these tasks consist of multiple jaunts of 400+ meters of travel and all this running quickly becomes dull even with the jetpack your character is supplied with (The jets are primarily for upward mobility rather than lateral movement).  While there do exist ways to expedite the time involved in travel by way of gliders and temporary vehicles (With, as I understand it, permanent vehicles available at level 25?  Apologies if I'm wrong in this regard as I was unable to keep motivated to play to that point).

I personally experienced combat as the Engineer frame and was rather unimpressed with it overall.  The frame's primary weapon is a dual purpose beam weapon that can damage enemies or repair friendly structures, but I found myself having to expend 60% or more of my weapon's ammunition on targets on a fairly consistent basis in spite of receiving weapon upgrades at a fairly decent pace.  This was made more unfortunate by the fact that you can only carry a maximum of four full reloads for your primary weapon and this led to me mainly using my secondary weapon.  The engineer frame starts out with a shotgun as a secondary and I just found the weapon outright appalling.  I found that I had to pretty much be point blank and dead center on a target to deal a worthwhile amount of damage to any enemy.  Later I switched to using an SMG as a secondary weapon.  It had better accuracy at range but I quickly found myself having to reload its 65 round magazine multiple times to deal with enemies of equal level using an SMG that was of my level.  The saving grace to these secondary weapons is that your ammunition for them is infinite...but in practice they seem to be rather weak in utility.

I can't speak for later game but the game rather quickly lost my interest early in, and if a game cannot hold interest through the early stages that speaks of a considerable flaw with it as a whole.  As it stands now I cannot recommend that you spend a considerable amount of time playing Firefall, though if you simply have some time to kill and space on your hard drive you could do far worse.

If nothing else, give the game a few months to get on its feet before making any real investments on it.

reviewText:
Very, Very buggy. Glitches that sometimes prevent you from advancing further in the mission, major graphical glitches and Pay 2 Win. The community can be helpful at times but it is extremely fanboyish, even if you point out a bug they instantly turn hostile

Crafting is complex and a pain, by the time you get the needed supplies for a item you have researched (crafting is in 4 stages, collecting raw materials, Refining, Researching Then Manufacturing said item) you have already passed the level where it becomes useful.

The Marketplace is also overly complex and not helpful, there is no tutorial to help you for it and it goes something like this; To sell an item you need to create a sell order for said item so someone can pick the order up and purchase the item for credits (the player currency) or you could fill in a buy order where the person who wants to buy something puts in a order for someone selling to fill it (no one ever creates legitimate buy orders that is not spam like 500 of 1 item for 1 credit)

There is no fast way to travel early in game unless you want to spend some money IRL to buy a permenant vehicle so the only way you can travel without reaching level 25 (which takes roughly 30 hours of pure gameplay for a new player) or using 1 use, bad vehicles which you have a chance to get from slot machines is to buy one of the games packages for XX amount of 'Red Beans' which is a currency you buy with real money to purchase just about anything, even advanced versions of the default classes for 100 beans each, which of course, is a rip off.

You can convert Crystite (a material you get from refining, killing, doing missions etc etc but you use for crafting) into credits for 1:25 which is only useful to use in end game when you are making too much Crystite or have no use for it as you have researched everything you need. However there is a conversion max you can do each day (i believe it is 1000 however im not sure) and the same you can do for Red Beans however it is much more credits to convert for a single Red Bean.

You can buy 'pilots licenses' from the marketplace which gives you access to the advanced classes that you can purchase with credits however it costs roughly 2000 credits for a single license on average as they do fluctuate which adds up to roughly 50,000 Crystite!

Please note this review is not complete and I did not have sufficent time to complete it all in one sitting, I will add more to it in further detail at a later date

reviewText:
Firefall is a fun game to play, when you're actually playing it. When you're wandering around the world aimlessly or waiting for quests to load or when you run out of jet fuel right before you get over the top of a mountain, it's a royal pain in the ♥♥♥.

Firefall has had a massively troubled development history and basically seems to have been pressured by the investors to release the game in an unfinished state.

So, the game feels unfinished. The content is for the most part monotonous and lacking much in the way of imagination. Things that were good about the game in beta have been butchered and new players without stacks of prior resources are going to have a ROUGH time levelling up their first character.

The basic mechanics behind the game are rock solid and it's great moving around and shooting things. Unfortunately every recent change they've made has gotten in the way of doing this and I can't really recommend trying with it until they do some MAJOR (and I mean major) fixes. I enjoy playing it, but I wouldn't wish it on a new person without the same resources as I had having played the game during its Beta.

reviewText:
I have played Firefall Since first day of open beta. Saw alot of changes, good and bad ones. But recently i decided to check on release and i was totally dissapointed. So, if you liked complex old crafting system and good rewarding thumping in pockets - then move along. Nothing for you there. So here's my impression and feedback.

- Game became alot more friendly to new players, also alot more easier
- Crafting got simplified as maximum as possible. You don't need to worry abough energy, weight and stats. You just craft pre-defined items every time.
- Thumping now can be done blindfolded. Resource veins is a total mess - there is a huge lack of resource quantity. So thumping is a pain now really.
- Battlframes. Have levels now - takes ages to grind. Gear got simplified as well. No more servos, jumpjets and platings. Just core and weapons. Also repair pools are gone and now gear is permanent and can't broke. You can repair it as much as you like. Right now you just grind the best gear and that's it.
Missions. New field missions are just the same as ARES just another name. Slight imprivement tho - voiced dialogs and some kind of a story. Still boring.
- Currency and Market. Biggest con for me. New currency been added - credits. Once per 24 hours you can exchange 25k CY for 1k credits. Now you need credits for everything. Prices are rediclous. White metal and purple metal costs the same. Very frustrating to use. Crystite became almost useless.

Again - just my opiniion and impressions as old player. Right now alot of things are broken
ot working as intended\missing or w\e. Some changes are just weird\stupid. Honestly after i played for a bit i just feel that i don't have any desire to log in back. I know things most likely gonna change. I loved this game, really. And i don't want to bash it but this just plain redicilous.
You still feel free to try.

reviewText: Almost a good game. I played it quite a bit for over a week and thought this would be my new main mmo. I level my Recon class to level 12 and decide to pony up some cash for a game I was enjoying to buy one of the advanced Recon battleframes, the Nighthawk. I've never left a bad review for a game in my life but this design just blew me away at how ridiculous it was. It's disrespectful to the time and money I invested in the game. I will not start over while playing the same base class, that is ridiculous. Uninstalling.

reviewText:
I loved this game and I hate to add some perspective but I still see it listed as Mostly Positive on the reviews, it went from 90% positive to about 70% positive all with the release of 1.6. Don't let my 500ish hours on record fool you, I played back in closed beta and before it came out on steam my character had literally thousands of hours on it, I don't use the steam client anymore either because it seems to be more buggy than the stand alon release.

Short Review:
The 1.6 patch made it so that new players were locked into a single frame (class) which in most MMO's wouldn't be an issue but Firefall was about freedom to swap classes at will. They changed almost every class from the 1.3 standards and weakened every stat on them. Crafting and high level zones (DT & Amazon) are currently suspended. Thumping doesn't yield resources but a small amount of crystite (in game currency). The new tinkering system requres credits which you can buy with red beans (real money exchange currency) and crystite (at 25k CY for 1k credits), originally credits were listed as the player to player purchase currency. PvP is back, but only one map and game type. Most vendors are broken in Sertao (30-40 zone now). Instances are broken into several types: Standard level and Challenge level seem to work fine. Hardcore (lvl 40) missions are 50/50 as to if it will launch for you. Hardcore Operations are buggy on launch and some times don't launch. Raid (yes singular) doesn't always launch and currently has a bug with the final phase so it's 50/50 if you'll be able to complete it. They took out 3 other raids: Baneclaw (expected to return in 1.7), Kanaloa (no return date yet) and Warfront (no return date yet). The Red Bean store went to rentals over purchases, thus you only get to rent the nice bikes then have to pay again next month. So in conclusion they took away most of what make Firefall Special, removed 70% of the content, and made it so if you do buy into thier game you get nothing in return.

Long review:

Pro's:
Free to play - if you don't buy beans
Ability cooldowns are very short

Con's:
All the frames feel similar
very little diversity in play styles
feels like every other shooter on the market with slightly better jumps
no more ZipZaping the chosen, they are no longer confused by mid-air acrobatics
Cover is the only defense against chosen fire
no crafting
no thumping
no new player frame switching
buggy quests (called jobs)
Hardcores rarely work right
Operations rarely launch
Only one Raid, takes about 30 mins.

I can't even play it anymore much less recomend it to new players. The game went from alot of fun to a pointless grind with real world money sinks. It feels like they are running out of money and trying to get the player base to pay for further development, the parent company The9 is ignoring player feedback and focusing on the Chinese Console release. From the direction the game has gone I would expect that the game will be shutting down in the US EU areas before long, players are leaving in hordes, the bad reviews are piling up, support tickets are getting stupid responces to bugs. IE they have 2 inventory tabs Inventory and Account Items. Account items are apparently character bound and character specific so account items not showing on all character on the account is Working as Intended" which seems to be the responce to 90% of the strange bugs. the other responce is "We're working on a fix."

Understand I waited a month hoping they would fix the bugs they introduced
date: no luck. After over 3 years of playing I'm leaving firefall at this time

reviewText:
Full disclosure: Beta tester, so I'm biased on this and that.

In a nutshell the game isn't what it used to be but deserves a chance for what it wants to do and it's community.  It has a jetback-and-plasma-cannon gameplay that's reminiscent of Starship Troopers Mobile Infantry (the novel!) Some have said it's also similar to global agenda.

What's everyone missing? A long, long time ago Copacobana felt... alive. Y'know. Like a real place. There would be wildlife scurrying through the undergrowth, players everywhere. Even thermal updrafts that blew your gliders higher for more exploration. There was only one zone available for a while, which was smaller, granted - but much more seamless.

There's just less players now, which is a result of the mission system forcing less players per given shard. You also had no level-gating to keep you from joining friends whenever you wanted, and people helping each other was both more commonplace and more meaningful.

I know that vertical progression brings in the money and is more financially viable. Yes, I know there's hardware limitations on how many events you can have. But it feels so ♥♥♥♥ing barren sometimes in the game. It doesn't help there's no real progression after level 40 on a frame except spamming missions for better loot.

Why am I sticking with Firefall? Well, despite the screw-ups in the past, I really like Red 5 as a studio. They listen, they patch fast, they've fostered a great community. They've also been working their asses off with new events to bring in new people. So hopefully it keeps getting better and more like the game we all loved before.

reviewText: The good: this game had (and perhaps still has) potential.  The gameplay is intended to be fluid and fairly rapidly-paced.  The questing (other than campaign quests) is fairly 'lite' on the story and I enjoyed the possibility of 'leveling' the same character in different roles in a way that made sense.  Red 5s stance on cheating is delightfully straighforward.  There are plentiful simple semi-randomized quests with middling rewards.\n\nThe bad:  There were several quests I could not finish due to bugs.  There was a quest with a node in 'deep water' (think damage zones) which, once you used, you took damage until you died (which then teleported me two zones away to a different respawn point).  There were two quests that sat at loading next waypoint" (or the equivalent
date: I forget the exact wording) the quest wouldn't progress
recommended: and relogging cleared the quest from your active quests.  Finally
hoursPlayed: as Acidule mentioned in his review
voteText: the tuning for enemy advancement is rather awkward.  You usually fight packs of 3-12 mooks at a time
helpfulPercent: and a large pack of equal-level ones will kill you.  I feel like if their net code was better
votesHelpful: this would be less of an issue.  (I run off broadband with sub 15ms ping and 90/25 mb bandwidth so there is no shortage on my end).  A further point brought up in another review is the decidedly monetized feel for a lot of what I would consider fairly basic things.  Inventory isn't an issue at relatively low level (although with all the different crafting materiels I could see it becoming one) but purchasing more slots requires use of the cash currency.  As do most of the permanent travel options.  I wouldn't have expected the vehicles to be such a big issue
votesTotal: however there is *SO MUCH RUNNING* needed that I can only feel they are trying to perform the same "2nd-class citizen" action that has ruined the appeal of so many other F2P games.  There is a big difference between "freemium" games where you get either cosmetic or minor benefits and ones that feel 'gated' by the payment requirements.\n\nBottom line
votesFunny: if this game was still listed as being in beta
commentsCount: I could be much more forgiving of the flaws and bugs.  I may give it another shot in a few weeks or months to see if there are any improvements or fixes... Then again

reviewText:
I have been a player during the alphas of this game. I have spent a lot of hours on this game before it came to Steam.

The game needs some work. But is it really that bad to mean that you shouldn't play? No, not really. They have reset class trees a little too often but it is all in the interest of the game. It really shouldn't happen this often though.

This has led to a lot of negative reviews on Steam. People who have spent a lot of hours have had their stuff wiped - but not quite... In return they are given a LOT of XP in the form of packs. PLUS gear. You didn't really miss out.

The developers aren't great. They need to realise what they have here and honestly discover the gem and possibilities they have. SO many people love this game and even those who have quit, I am sure would love to see this game become great.

TL:DR - It's worth playing. The developers could be better, but it's still a great game. Don't pay too much attention to mad people posting negative reviews for selfish reasons.

reviewText: Game was great during v0.8 but v1.0 did a major overhaul, while most of the changes were great the biggest deal breaker was introducing leveling zones, removing horizontal progression, replacing it with vertical progression. Unfortunately the world map was designed with the system of horizontal progression, flipping it to vertical has segmented the world map up and has made the world feel small and linear.\n\nI cannot recommend this game to anyone. Until they remove the leveling system and reverted it back to v0.8.

reviewText: Very grindy boring questing. quests consist of nothing more than either go to location, defend location, or go to location, kill enemies or go to location collect item THEN kill enemies. I just checked in to what is supposed to be the pvp area and I was literally the only person in the zone. The combat mechanics are mediocre at best, all the classes while different inappearance and abilities somehow manage to feel all too similiar. (possibly due to the lack of npc AI which for the most part just requires you to stand aim and shoot at the enemy to take them down, unless presented with a swarm then maybe you'll need some cover) Travelling is a pain as if you want to get anywhere quickly, in fact if you want to do just about anything outside the bounds of running around grinding in one of the boring basic classes you better be ready to shell out some cash. There are ways to implement free to play games and this game is on the very wrong side of the spectrum. They SAY this is a AAA title, but for a game thats been in developement for longer than most mmos actually survive these days by a AAA company, you wouldnt be able to tell. It's closer to some of the greenlit indie developed garbage you see on steam these days.

reviewText: As you can see I've not played much Firefall. Why then am I writing a review? And why would I not recommend it? After my 5th attempt the Tutorial continues to bug out, not just for me but everyone who was in the tutorial with me based on the chat. It gets you about 30 yards from the starting point then throws up an invisable wall and no one can progress beyond it no matter what people tried. Relogging caused it to reset the tutorial (including upskippable intro) and the bug continued. Highly annoying as the game looks promising beyond the tutorial, but in it's current state and with my current experience I CANNOT recommend this game to anyone as there isn't even a game to recommend with that bug in the way.

reviewText:
A solid game with its up and downs. It went through a developer hell (you can research if you want to know) to arrive at its current state.
You are an ARES agent equpped with a battleframe. There are 5 classes of frames each with 2-3 advanced subclasses. Assault, Dreadnaught, Engineer, Recon & Biotech are the basic ones available right away. To unlock an advanced sub-class frame you need to level any already unlocked frame to 40. Alternatively, you can just buy a pilot license with cash or purchase one off the player market. The latter method involves a decent amount of grinding as in-game currency is harder to come by than usual.
The game game certainly has its charm - the colourful world, a few interesting personalities, fresh combat. But all of that is balanced out by the monotony of grind once the initial novelty passes, the somewhat boring crafting system and a rudimentary player economy.
While the release version is quite OK there are some things that turned to worse since closed beta. The game's resource and crafting system went through many iterations, some more in-depth than the others. At present you can only boost any one base stat of your frame with mutually exclusive 'cores'. I see this as a huge step back as before you were able to boost most stats by crafting better battleframe components. Jumpjets allowed you to have a better, faster boost, plating gave you armour and health/regen, servos were responsible for run/sprint speed and jump height and so on.
Weapon and other gear crafting has gone through some dramatic changes as well. As the game is right now, crafting anything except the highest tier gear is pointless as you'd have to grind for resources and, chances are, you'll sooner get an item drop comparable to the one you're looking to craft.

If you want a few hours of fun the game will deliver, but beyond that it turns into a grind-fest to get to end-game of which there is very little. Keep an eye out for future content updates. Hopefully, those will improve and expand Firefall.

reviewText:
So far I’ve played this for a hour and a half or so. It’s good for what it is, but it’s not my thing.

http://youtu.be/BoenItmBfSA
I didn’t really know anything about this game before today. So I wasn’t sure what to expect. When it said FPS MMO I thought maybe that would mean it’s sort of like Planetside. But it’s not like that, so far it feels like a cross between WOW and borderlands. Gameplay is primarily PVE. I’ve pretty much only played solo so far. I mainly found myself taking one quest, travelling to a location, killing a set number of hostile aliens, picking up an item and returning to the quest giver. Unfortunately for me after having played WOW and borderlands before it felt very ‘been there, done that’. Especially with having to travel by foot to objectives, why would I want simulate walking? But it still feels better than what I remember WOW being like which is the main MMORPG that I’ve played. I really wanted to just to get stuck into some team PVE instances or PVP matches. I did participate in what I think was a matchmade coop PVE instance. But I didn’t have a lot of time to look at that today which sucks, because it actually started to get interested once I reached that. There is supposed to be PVP as well but I didn’t have a chance to experience that today. After a little bit of research I found how you’re supposed to add yourself to the queue for that but it didn’t work for me. And I haven’t found any information about when you are able to do that. I can only assume that I need to progress further in order to unlock PVP matchmaking. One feature that I did like in this was the jetpack ability, that’s a cool if limited way to move around.

Initially I felt that the graphics were actually below what I expected. I felt maybe the textures weren’t that detailed. I really got sense that the game is geared towards being able to support action on a large scale i.e. large scale battles with a large amount of players. But actually after playing it for a while I felt that the graphics aren’t bad at all. The cutscenes and dialogue in the beginning I didn’t really pay a lot of attention to because I really just wanted to get stuck into the game. So I can’t really say much about the lore and the story

What are you getting with this game. It’s sort of a Borderlands like experience that costs nothing. If you really like MMORPG games this might be right for you. At this stage I don’t know how restricted you are in the long run as non-paying player. But hopefully you are not put at an extreme disadvantage if you don’t invest money into the game. I would have liked to have just been able to engage in PVP combat right from start. If I get around to it I want to do more on PVE instances and PVP matches in this game hopefully do a let’s play on it/add more to my review. That’s all I have to say about this game for today.

reviewText:
Just want to point out I've been playing since 2012 and steam hours are just from the steam client.

Whatever you do don't use the steam client. For some reason it is filled with more bugs than the client from the actual website.

Firefall wise, this game is pretty awesome. I feel bad for the new players though because you only get to choose one battleframe and you can't change unless you pay money or get it to level 40.  In the beta you started out with all the accord frames and had to unlock the others.

Gameplay wise it is fun, you can switch between first person and third person, glide around, grind resources, quest, craft, get pets, and play different classes. The crafting system is intense and requires you to thump" for resources.

Thumping is basically an auto mine feature where you guard the thumping device from constant waves of enemies that get harder and harder the longer you "thump" or mine for resources. This is what you will be doing for a really big portion of the game. The only downside to this is that it can get really redundant and boring. Just take a break and do something else and go back to it!

You can also join other players in thumping and recieve a portion of the resources they are thumping. The bigger the thumper the harder it will be to defend it. It doesn't take away from what the owner of the thumper recieves so dont be afraid to hop in and help. Free xp and resources! Can't complain.

The red beans are the cash shop of the game. Pretty well balanced in my opinion
date: I think the battleframes are a little pricey at around 15 dollars per frame. Each frame cost 100 beans (or get a frame to level 40). 50 bucks will get you 4 frames (450 red beans) because you get bonus beans for buying in bulk so obviously the more beans you buy the cheaper the frame.  If thats all you buy then basically you have bought yourself a game anyways so do your research and pick 4 frames to love. Or just get frames to level 40 and unlock them yourself.\n\nAll in all it is fully free to play

reviewText:
Very good, fun game. I've heard a lot of criticism about it, and frankly, I don't see it. Here are some of the major problems people have with the game.

1. Transportation is only available after level 25 - While true, what you have to realise is that that is level 25 on one class. There are a total of 16 classes, meaning that level 25 is relatively early in the game. In addition, I've only been playing Firefall for 36 hours, at this point, and I have leveled one class to level 23, another to 15, and the other three basic ones to 6/7. So, it doesn't actually take that long to progress anyway.

2. Pay to win - This is absolutely not true. Because of the way the currency system works, you can convert in-game currency to Red Beans, which is the paid-for currency. Therefore, it is possible to earn any item you want just by playing the game. Yes, it will take time and effort, but the alternative is for everything to simply be given to the player, negating all semblance of progression. Not to mention the fact that most of the things that you buy with Red Beans are vanity items anyway.

3. No variations on weapons - I put this claim down to people not playing the game long enough. While yes, each class has only one type of weapon that they can use, they do vary somewhat. For example, the Assault's weapon is a plasma cannon, with an alt-fire of a shotgun-style blast. Around level 18 or so, I found blueprints for a version that spits fire instead - it keeps the feel of the Assault's weapon, but with a slightly different twist. In addition, I am now level 23 on the Assault, and I haven't found a replacement, so it's definitely paid off.

4. No variation on abilities - This is basically the same problem as the above, but I didn't want to write too much in one section. I've heard some people complain that at level 8 (when you unlock your 4th ability), you don't get anything new. This is far from the case. You unlock new abilities at level 15 and 23, which means that you will need to switch out abilities and try new things. The amount of levelling between these abilities is such that it gives you a chance to try the new abilities and playstyles, without letting the game stagnate too much.

These are the 4 things I've found to be the most common 'downsides' to the game, and personally, I don't think they stand up. My belief is that people who complain about this game do not understand what the game is about. Firefall is *not* a normal FPS. It is a MMO, first and foremost, which is why I do not understand why people complaining about having to work for their rewards. I do not claim to know everything about MMOs, but Firefall doesn't feel particularly grindy to me. Personally, I think people judge Firefall as an FPS first, when it is an MMO. The majority of people that I have seen bad reviews from have judged the game around level 8-12, without giving the game a chance to show it's diversity.

Obviously, this game will not be everyone's favourite, but it is for me. Also, for people who say that the game has become worse since beta, I played this game during beta, and it was too complicated for my taste. Firefall is currently in a much more enjoyable state.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The game is fun for some hours at the beginning but once you've done a couple of missions, jobs, and things like that the game gets incredibly repetitive. In order to unlock missions (that's basically the story of the game) you have to reach a certain level, and in order to level up you of course need xp, and the only way to get it is either a couple of side events, jobs or thumping, and that's it. The jobs get extremely repetitive, it always sends you LONG distances to the waypoint, and once you reach the waypoint there's little to no things to do, you either kill things, defend something by killing waves of things or it's an escort mission where you have to travel a whole kilometer and defend the person you're escorting to a certain waypoint by killing things. And there is little enemy variety. Once you're done with 1 objective you get another, take a guess what you need to do in the next objective... That's right! Kill things that are miles away. Once you reach level 25 you get a LGV ( motorbike ) recipe which helps you get to places faster, but that doesn't solve the problem that for EVERY SINGLE JOB you need to kill things AND NOTHING ELSE. In the game there are about 4-5 classes and each class branches about in about 2-3 different styles of the class, for example you have the basic Recon class with a mid-long range assault rifle, and the class branches out to a recon class with a long range bolt action rifle ( Nighthawk ) but in order to unlock a different class apart from the basics you need to max out any class to level 40 which as you may have guessed already, takes a craplot of grinding\n\nMy final verdict for the game would be 4/10

reviewText:
Extensive and edited review don't be fooled by the review date!

A great addictive game!

Red 5 made an awesome game for players who are just like me and want to get payed... virtually!

A small playerbase!
This can change if you invite friends and play: https://accounts.firefall.com/account/friend_invites

It has amazing atmosphere!
The music is superb!
A huge futuristic melded world to explore!
You can buy and sell red beans! (credit to red bean sell costs vary on patches)
The voice actors are pretty good but some of them are replaced temporarily until R5 can pay for it.

New updates, changes and fixes to the game!
Red5 updates the game every month or so if we support them by buying red beans. The company who shares Red 5 (The9) keep this game running since the CEO Mark Kern got fired and most of the devs got layed off.

A minor setback: When I enter comabt and roam the game rubber bands.

They added a new zone: Devils Tusk and did a lot of bug fixes and updates on patch 1.7!

Their support is very good although it takes them a while to respond to people from last patches and resolve their problems. I got contacted 12 days later and I got my character back and the promotional AMD paint and decal with it!

Daily login bonuses!
When you login you're greeted with a screen that you click to get a random item. When you play the game over time you get a random amount of items as well!

Bounties!
You can get daily objectives that you complete to get experience, crystite, a crate containing items for battleframes and more!

Perk system!
You can select perks to use when you have enough bandwidth you can choose more perks. You can switch perks everyday or buy a reset for red beans.

There are elite ranks!
Once you reach level 45 you go onto elite ranks!
Every 10 elite ranks you get a chance of a new advanced batleframe!

All in all a great game if you want something different than fantasy mmorpg's pick this up!

My IGN is BetaParty see you in game!

reviewText:
So, another free MMO is on the market and why should you even try this one?
You can view Firefall as a bledn of Planetside 2, Borderlands and a bit of Global Agenda.
As such its a lot more of a shooter than your basic MMO, which if you like shooters is REALLY GOOD!

Althow it is an MMO it doesnt feel like it, it feels like you're actualy playing your standard co-op game.
And it mostly does that through the excellent voice acted missions that you get through a Job board.
Now, the missions may not always include you doing something very different every time, but the game makes you care about what you are doing. Are you helping a mother find her son? Are you helping some civilans getting food?
The game atleast says what you're doing and that can instantaniously makes you care. And the voice acted bits aren't shoved down your throat like in The old Republic, they are just some messages that you recive and they dont hinder your gameplay.
But unlike in the old Republic, your character is silent and doesn't talk at all (they do even joke about it).

But let us talk more about the combat. As i said, the game feels more of a co-op game, and even in combat that is clearly visible. Your main source of dispercing damage is your GUN! That means that combat is more Borderlands-esk and even the enemy variety is closely similar to that of Borderlands. But you also have 4 abilities, 3 that you use and have a cool down and the forth ability charges through combat.

But besides your regular missions Firefall is also structured to have a more dynamic feel to it. You will find your fellow players gathering resources and some side-mission, which you can ither start yourself or help your fellow soldiers in the field.
The gathering of the resources is especialy fun, since it is more of a team oriented thing and you and your friends are besacly just mowing down bugs and enemys as they come coming towards you.

There is also a crafting sistem, which works like your usuall crafting sistem with some twists (i have never seen a lot of the crafting sistems in other MMOs). Firstly you need to research what you want to make, and then actualy make it. Fearly basic, but the hard part is actualy juggeling your resources/money.

I have mixed feeling on the business model. The devs sure need to make money and i belive they might have actualy been able to get a functioning sistem into their game that is not really pay to win. In game, you can buy red bean coins with real money, that in turn allow you to buy special items from the Red Bean store. Most of these items are luxurious, like a bike (you can make one yourself for free to) and some other cosmetic items. The only problem i have is that the giant gameplay changing item, the one that allows you to play different classes (battleframes) is (for me) kinda costly, since you can pay 10€ just for another run in the game with some different abilities.
But its not as bad as it sounds right now. You can actualy earn those Red Bean coins ingame, for free! You can excange your basic money, to credits (which are used for the marketplace) and then those into Red Bean coins. Sure the excange isn't exactly linear, but you can earn the Bean coins without spendint a dime.
How ever, the time it takes you to aquire even an usable amount of Bean coins, so it is still very harsh, but hey, you can speed things up with spending money and supporting the devs.


In short, Firefall is in my opinion one of the finest MMOs and if you liked Borderlands, Planetside 2 or Global Agenda, you should give this one a look. The begining few levels might be boring, but after you get into the game a bit it just takes off and unlike some MMOs that have you just spaming some abilities you can actualy have tons of fun here!
voteText: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was in the beta for this and it really had hopes burning high. It has some really interesting ideas to it and if one is a diehard fan of third-person shooters you might like it but it is dogged by problems.

I rate F2P model as fair, there is no content that affects gameplay that cannot be acquired in a reasonable amount of time without paying and there are purely aesthetic items can be bought with real money alone, though the appearance of characters can become a little generic I don't see this as a problem.

The game is buggy though, possibly more so from the beta days as it's virtually unplayable. Missions stopped updating in my mission journal, one stuck at loading next waypoint, the tutorial mission bugged out and remain in my journal with the last objective even though I completed it the day before.

The server was very laggy, at the last login it was continually beeping with a server lag warning and other players were getting this same message. Even outside of these warnings, lag was a constant companion.

I don't recommend this game.

reviewText:
So, this is a don't recommend, but it isn't wasn't a bad game really. Allow me to explain.

There's this other game, called Defiance (launched April 2, 2013). It's essentially the same game. Now, since Firefall was launched July 29, 2014, you'd think it would be better... well, it's not, it's... just different.

Similarities:
Both third person MMORPGs
Something" happened that made the Earth as we know it.
This "something" transmutated the fauna / flora.
There are different classes for your character.
You can level up your character.
There is a tech tree.
There are weapon mods.
You can upgrade your characters personal equipment.
There are bugs. Why always bugs. Anyway
date: think 'bug like extra-terrestrial animals'.\nThere are multiple areas
recommended: as per any MMORPG\nThere are quests - again MMORPG.\nYou play an alignment where the locals don't take too kindly to you. But you earn their respect by not being a turd
hoursPlayed: and helping them.\nThere's a local presence by the world wide millitary
voteText:
then don't like you much either
... look you get the idea.

Differences:
In Firefall
helpfulPercent: you're an ARES pilot - in Defiance
votesHelpful: you're an ARK Hunter.\nIn Firefall
votesTotal: there's the option of being an Engineer. (yay!) You can place turrets etc.\nIn Firefall
votesFunny: If you get in too much water
commentsCount: you fritz out your power armor. <insert no swimming sign here>\nUmmmm. They call their in-game currencies different names :D\nOh! In Firefall

column18: and sometimes downright unhelpful. And it's because of this

but enough not to be lonely.

reviewText: Fun open world MMOFPS. Beautiful environments, great graphics, fun gameplay. Couldn't ask for more from a game. Especially a free one. If you played in beta absolutely give this game another chance, I understand that most games don't change very drastically from beta to launch, but this game is the exception. When I played in closed beta there was basically no content. You started out crafting and thats all you did the entire time. Guard your thumper. They've changed it COMPLETELY. They've added dynamic events constantly goin on in the open world, a massive open world PvP map, tons and tons of quests and probably a ton of stuff I don't even know about. It takes a lot to impress me these days when it comes to MMO's but Firefall has definitely done it.

reviewText:
UPDATE:  Skip to the end for impressions on the new War in the Amazon content and faction changes.

I'm coming up on 400 hours of gameplay in this fellow, so I suppose I should write a review of some sort.   Much has already been written about Firefall, and while I recommend the game to anyone looking for an action MMO, I almost feel like anything I say would hardly encapsulate the game because it is always changing and shifting (with a major endgame area to be debuted in the next few weeks after I write this).

I suppose what most people want to know when reading user comments on this game is: is it actually free to  play or is it Freemium" nonsense where the game is basically unplayable past a certain point without investing lots of money?  Well
date: I can definitely attest: this game really and truly is free to play.  There is no content behind paywalls and while real money can
hoursPlayed: buy you better in-game equipment and such
voteText: everything in the game can be obtained
helpfulPercent: in some manner
votesHelpful: through gameplay.   Now
votesTotal: I won't lie....paying for the VIP membership is probably the smart course for a player who enjoys the game
votesFunny: but the game is not unplayable without it.  People who spend lots of real money for in-game currency to buy stuff off the player market will have an advantage in PvP
commentsCount: I won't lie
column16: but as PvP is an entirely seperate part of the game
column17: the PvE kinda benefits from having some people with purchased items.\nHaving said all that
column18:
here's my brief pros/cons rundown:

Pros:
-Interesting variations in gameplay and playstyle based on the class you choose.
-The perk system allows interesting synergies between different classes since the different classes can actually share most of the perks that you earn from leveling.
-The game only uses ONE character who has access to all of the class "Frames"
column19:
which makes sharing equipment easier and helps with leveling frames that are around the same level.
-The singleplayer "jobs" actually bother to try telling a coherent story about the setting and background of the game.
-A healthy amount of open world content that gives players a break from just doing jobs to level their frames.
-Once you complete major milestones in the game once (like unlocking new areas etc.) the stuff unlocks for your successive frames
column20: so you have more freedom and options with your lower level frames as you get further into the game.\n-Large-scale open world events allow for fun
column21: co-op play with other players without being too exclusionary for lower level or newer players (although there are some basic level limits on certain things).\n-The ability to "thump" (mine for your own crafting resources) adds an interesting
column22:
self-initiated activity to the game.
-Players share exp and loot for open world events in a very fair manner and no one player can either take all the rewards or prevent other players from getting their rewards either.

Cons:
-The game balance
column23: in terms of overall difficulty
column24: is problematic at times and is always being tinkered with.  (as I write this
column25: major updates to how combat functions are being planned probably to be implimented in the next month or two)\n-A fairly good chunk of the usual bugs and glitches that large
column26: open world MMOs have.  Some are generally fixed fairly fast
column27: while others have been around for ages without hope of being fixed any time soon.\n-Getting around the world can be awkward and slow even with vehicles and gliders and other assistance.  One entire section of the game (Sertao
column28: the world for characters lvl 25-35) has no means of quick travel at all except to go back to the exit/entrance travel points.\n-The "advanced" frames are sometimes very superior to the normal
column29: free
column30: counterparts
column31: making the base frames a little on the weak or disadvantaged side.\n-The major server events do not happen with anywhere near enough frequency
column32: in my opinion.  All major events at this point only occur once an hour which can sometimes make areas of the game very barren of content depending on the time of day.\n-Special open world content rated for single players is not even remotely able to be finished by solo players
column33: and often requires several people.\n-The in-game crafting system
column34: while very useful and functional for character up to about level 30-32 becomes so insanely grindy and impractical in the later game that there is almost no point in using it to supply characters above lvl 32 or so.\n-Some of the instances and special missions have serious issues with what kind of loot they reward.  This is slowly being improved
column35: but right now it is often not worth the time it takes to do some of the more advanced
column36: end-game instances and such.\n\nLike any MMO
column37: there are players who take a lot of things about this way too seriously and will often have a negative effect on the overall community
column38: but anyone who just wants to have fun taking out some bad guys and maybe joining some large-scale events will find a lot to like here.  Just be aware that a lot of content and features have been added to the game over a relatively short period of time
column39: so things are always being tweaked and modified.  The community
column41: has been very positive and the strong focus on PvE means that most players understand the benefits of helping out each other.\nIf
column44: Firefall might not satisfy you much.  While the game has an entire world set aside for PvP
column45: it suffers from a few major problems; mostly balance and the fact that not many people play in those areas.  PvP will probably undergo major changes as well in the coming months
column46: but right now I cannot reccomend Firefall for people who want the PvP aspect as a strong element of the game.\n\nDamn...it's almost impossible to really get into everything in this game except to say: just give it a try for a bit and see what you think.  The community is usually pretty helpful and I always try my best to help out newer players.  There is also a strong "mentor" system in the game where players get appointed as mentors.  A few of the mentors are jerks
column47: but they get weeded out pretty fast.\n\nOh
column48: and one more thing...the game is very playable with an Xbox controller (support for which is built-in) but you will have to fiddle with it to get it where you want it.  There are a lot of hot keys in the game and it's not possible to operate the entire game witn a controller
column49: but the bulk of the game (running around and shooting things) can be done very well with a controller.\n\nUPDATED STUFF:  So
column50: not long after I wrote this
column51: Red 5 did indeed add the "War in the Amazon" content and a new faction system
column52: which changes some aspects of my review.\n\nThe Amazon is a new region of the game geared solely towards high-level
column53: end-game characters (the game says it's only for level 40 players
column54: but I think level 37+ could probably handle themselves OK)  It's difficult to describe the region if you are not already familiar with the game
column56: it's basically just a place for lvl 40 characters to go nuts because there's nearly constantly combat.  It's a lot of fun
column58: one of the downsides is that the rewards are not that great and you need a lot of people to take over the region.   The new faction system is amazing and gets rid of so much of the grind.  Instead of having to slowly earn faction currency to buy things
column59: you now just permanently earn reputation and can buy things with crystite (which is the standard currency) when you reach the appropriate faction level.  No more spending days of your life just trying to buy some high level abilities or weapons."

Started playing since it came out this year and got addicted to this FPS/MMO type of game. Have to say that it's a fun game to play with your friend's, siblings etc... This isn't one of those games you play that you have to spend money on ingame items to get the best gear or customization on your character out there, this game offers you a choice whether you buy game credits using real money or buy it using ingame currency.
I levelled 3 Battleframes to lvl40 now.

Here's my list on what to expect when you log your fist character:

1. You'll only have to use one character/avatar name.

3. Game's open world
date: theres dynamic events going on each zone/map that you travel in "That means more exp."\n4. Doing- Job board quests gives you "Vending Token's" that allows you to use on a vending machine- If you're lucky enough... You might get to unlock a headgear or any item customizations.\n5.  PvE is great with all the missions/instances/world missions. PvP is little
recommended:
theres Duels but open-world pvp is still being discussed.
6. Just jump in and play the game to find out more... Give it a try!

If you like shooter games and mmorpg's

reviewText: Firefall is a great MMORPG for it being Free to Play. Unlike most F2Ps, it doesn't act like a Pay to Win, rather Pay for convenience and cosmetics. It has an excellent crafting system, but it takes a while for the items to be completed. You can, however, pay 1 Red Bean, which is the game's paid currency, to instantly complete the crafting process. You aren't required to pay for Red Beans, however. With using the game's common currency, Crystite, you can obtain Credits, and convert those credits into Red Beans. You can obtain nearly everything in this game without spending anything, which I would like to see in more games. I didn't think this game would've changed much from the Beta, but it turns out that this game finally made it's way out of development hell. Replayable missions, great combat mechanics, fun dynamic events, good loot system, beautiful open-world, this game is really good and I think people should at least try it as it is Free to Play.

reviewText:
Firefall is a free-to-play sci-fi themed open-world cooperative PvE 3rd/1st person shooter MMORPG.  If you enjoyed Tabula Rasa back in the day, or you've played Global Agenda more recently, but wish they'd had a larger PvE zone, then you really owe it to yourself to give Firefall a try.  You should find each of the Firefall battleframes very familiar.

Firefall continues to be actively developed, and the developers are not afraid to try new things, keeping what works and modifying or retiring what doesn't.  The developers are also quite responsive to player feedback.  Don't expect every pet feature to be magically implemented, but quality of life improvements do get added and bugs do get fixed.  Many of the improvements implemented over the years have been the direct result of player feedback.  (So be sure to report any bugs you find using the “Submit Bug Report” button or by opening a ticket at support.firefall.com.  And be sure to submit feature requests on feedback.firefallthegame.com Don't just gripe on general chat.)

That does also mean that as the game continues to evolve, the older reviews you read about Firefall become increasingly outdated.  Those who played only at various points during the beta experienced an entirely different game than the one that is currently offered.  (I know.  I was there.)  Even those who played shortly after launch missed out on such quality of life improvements as the 1-hour daily XP/resource buff, daily login rewards, the level 15 and level 25 LGV (aka – motorbike) quest rewards, as well as the 10% permanent XP buff you earn for each battleframe you level to 40.  (Which makes the game fairly altaholic friendly.)  They'd also be missing out on the new world events like Brontodon King, OCT, and Skydock that are regular staples now, and are generally a lot of fun to participate in.

As I write this the 1.3 update was just released a couple days ago, adding a large new open-world endgame zone, War in the Amazon.  Vouchers from the job-boards have been replaced with a more player-friendly reputation system.  And blueprints for building your own LGV are now available at the start of the game.  The core game engine continues to be improved as well, most recently adding a new adaptive particle effects scaling feature that helps keep the frame rate up during large scale firefights.

In short, if you like the idea of a cooperative action MMORPG with lots of guns an explosions, Firefall is definitely worth a try.


Some advice for new players:

If you're motion sensitive, you may want to adjust the 1st and 3rd person FOV (field of view) sliders, the 3rd person camera zoom, 3rd person sprint zoom, and the camera animation check-box under options, gameplay, on the opening screen.  (I have my 3rd person FOV set to 110 with the camera and sprint zoom set at zero, and the camera animation turned off.)

If you're playing on an older computer and getting poor performance, try setting the shadow quality and model quality to LOW under options, graphics, advanced, on the opening screen.  Those two settings can give quite a performance boost for very little loss in video quality.  (If you're still getting poor performance, try lowering the texture resolution to medium or low as well.)

As soon as you have the materials collected, consider crafting yourself a stack of small stim packs, glider pads, and jump pads.  I usually keep those three things bound to my 6, 7, and 8 keys.  Using them along with the LGV, you'll be able to get around a lot easier and last a lot longer.  (Also note that you can earn a permanent glider pad by visiting every SIN tower in the game.)

If you're motion sensitive, you may want to adjust the 1st and 3rd person FOV (field of view) sliders, the 3rd person camera zoom, 3rd person sprint zoom, and the camera animation check-box under options, gameplay, on the opening screen.  (I have my 3rd person FOV set to 110 with the camera and sprint zoom set at zero, and the camera animation turned off.)

If you're playing on an older computer and getting poor performance, try setting the shadow quality and model quality to LOW under options, graphics, advanced, on the opening screen.  Those two settings can give quite a performance boost for very little loss in video quality.  (If you're still getting poor performance, try lowering the texture resolution to medium or low as well.)

As soon as you have the materials collected, consider crafting yourself a stack of small stim packs, glider pads, and jump pads.  I usually keep those three things bound to my 6, 7, and 8 keys.  Using them along with the LGV, you'll be able to get around a lot easier and last a lot longer.  (Also note that you can earn a permanent glider pad by visiting every SIN tower in the game.)

reviewText:
I started this game a little less than 2 weeks ago and I really like it. If you haven't played it yet, I suggest you give it a shot - it's FREE!!
Without getting too philosophical, I've noticed there are primarily two kinds of people that play this game...

Type 1: The realist. This person realizes the game occassionally has issues like any other MMO and they don't expect it to be perfect. This player knows that MMOs get repetitive and doesn't complain about it. This player knows that even though they like the game, they know it's not for everyone. I consider myself to be in this category. I like the game for what it is and don't whine about the game not always being 100% SuPeR AwEsOmE!!!!!". I know the game has some bugs now and then - all games do. Type 1 players diligently submit bug reports to the developers (who have always been very kind and helpful!!!) and focus their time on areas of the game not affected by the bug until it is fixed.

Type 2: The idealist. This person believes all games should be totally perfect and never have problems - not even little ones. They think that if they don't personally like the game
date: the game must be crap and undeserving of anyone's attention - ever. People that play this game for 100
hoursPlayed: even 300+ hours then leave a review about it being "too repetive
voteText: not all that fun
helpfulPercent: or too broken to play" are in this group. The idealist thinks that a game should be equally engaging at hour 1
votesHelpful: hour 50

reviewText:
Overall a good game, worth a try. An interesting mix of FPS/TPS and MMORPG.

Pros:
+ Decent voice acting.
+ Good variety of classes/Battleframes to choose. You get 5 basic Battleframes, that you can change at any time to suit your playstyle and additional 11 Battleframes, that you can unlock later.
+ Very large maps, with a lot of quests and dynamic quests that apear randomly. (world bosses, invasions, etc.)
+ Good gunplay combined with the skills of the Battleframe.

Cons:
- Quests are very similar to each other, for example: go to point A, kill some dudes or scan some trash, then go to point B, then kill some more dudes or scan some more trash, then go back to the questgiver. The Only quests that stand out are some story missions and dungeons/ instances.
- Leveling up Battleframes takes a long time.
- Large amount of bugs and glitches, which range from graphical bugs, sound bugs and even some nasty gameplay bugs. Restarting the game helps with most of these bugs, but still it's not great.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Why do I reccommend this game?
-Great visuals
-Fun exploration
-Nice class customization and freedom to swap between them.
-Battling for territory against NPC's (Even though it may be a small feature)
-varying scales of battles with NPC's during events, may require you to work together with others
-Great game to play while listening to podcasts.

What I (and you might also) dislike about this game:
-Repetitive missions
-Needs to give more incentive to us players so that we will WANT to max out our reputation with other factions and complete repetitive missions and events.

OVERALL, its a nice game that I would play while listening to a podcast or at a time where I just feel the need to get a quick game in to blow off some steam after a bad day.
If you plan on dedicating a good amount of your time, and money, to this game I suggest joining up with an Army" and making a few friends that you can run around and have fun with ingame as it seems that this is the type of game that can quickly turn into a boring chore.

I SUGGEST the developers look at updating the game with things such as adding more diverse missions and events
recommended: perhaps have more interaction between the player and the various factions to give more incentive to gaining their trust
hoursPlayed: or even allow the player to choose to gain the trust of the more evil factions. Anything to get rid of the repetitivenness currently plagueing the game
voteText: lest it divulge into a themepark MMO.\n\nIf I had to score this game

Let me explain that briefly: There used to be a BAJILLION resources, seriously look it up, and it was completely silly. They managed to trim it down to base resources, and it was certainly (unless you have some form of crazy you agree) a vast improvement. The problem is, this game with a complete dumbing down of the gear system. reviewText: Firefall is perhaps the best free-to-play game out there, and it certainly lives up to its promise of free - everything ingame can be acquired through actual effort, rather than paying and not having any kind of challenge. If paying's what you prefer, it is an option, but still. The gameplay is certainly fun - random events make trips to actual missions exciting, and you can fight anything from ten to hundreds of enemies at once. It's not absolutely perfect - there are plenty of bugs, and many veterans complain that war events used to be more of a challenge, but if you're looking for a decent game for the cost of nothing at all, this is the best you can get.\n9.5/10

reviewText: Although not groundbreaking in it's field of Indie and MMO RPGs, Firefall does have many great advantages to it and has a set uniqueness that is well worth the download. As a whole the game keeps the player involved and gives them a set goal that looms throughout the game while still maintaining the importance of side goals and missions. Besides this the graphics maintain a great quality throughout the game even on the lowest settings. It is worth noting that the game does have a slight pay to win" feel at first
date:
but with effort most if not all of the things that can be defined as "important" can be earned with time and not money. All this coupled with it's well written missions and stellar player interaction makes it a must have in most gamers' libraries.

9/10
Well worth the "nothing" it costs
Would recommend to most players interested in MMO RPGs and Indie type games"
